AA VV.Entry Details: Altesses Vôtres (Fr) your highnesses (See: FER- NANDO II of Tuscany).

Abbeville.Entry Details: commune of the Somme department, N France.

Abercrombie, Sir Robert.Entry Details: 1740-1827, British general in the French and Indian and the American Revolutionary Wars.

Abingdon.Entry Details: Abington, town in Plymouth county, Massachusetts.

Accademia Romana.Entry Details: the Roman Academy of Pomponio Leto for the study of Latin antiquity. In 1469 Pope Paul II (Pietro BARBO) closed the Accademia Romano, accusing Leto of conspiracy against the papacy and having Leto and Bartolomeo SACCHI thrown into prison.

ac ego in harum..Entry Details: (L) haram and I too in the pig-sty.

à ce que l'argent circule.Entry Details: (Fr) that money circulate. (See Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 23).

Achaia.Entry Details: Achaea, region of ancient Greece, N Peloponnesus, on Gulf of Corinth, later the Roman province, called Achaia, founded by Augustus.

Acoetes.Entry Details: the pilot of the ship taking DIONYSUS to NAXOS to marry Ariadne. The crew, not realizing his identity, attempts to abduct Dionysus, Dionysus causes tigers and leopards to appear on the ship, entwines the mast with vines, and turns the sailors into dolphins. Only Acoetes is spared. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, III; Homeric Hymn VII, To Dionysus).

Acre.Entry Details: the port in Palestine. ELEANOR of Aquitaine landed there on the Second Crusade (1146-49).

Actaeon.Entry Details: while hunting he came upon ARTEMIS bathing in the pool of GARGAPHIA, she changed Actaeon into a stag, and he was torn to pieces by his own dogs. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, III, 138-252).

Acta Sanctorum.Entry Details: (L) deeds of the saints. The name given to collections of biographies of saints and martyrs, especially to that of the Bollandists.

Actium.Entry Details: promontory and town, NW Arcanania, Greece, site of the battle (31 BC) between Octavian and the forces of Antony and Cleopatra

Actum in Castro Sigismundo.Entry Details: (L) Donc in the Castle Signsmund, before Roberto de VALTURIO/ freely and of clear knowledge

actus/ legis nulli facit injuriam.Entry Details: (L) an act of law does harm to none. (See: John Adams, Works, II, 159).

Adair, James.Entry Details: 13th-century trader in Georgia and the Carolinas, author of The History of the American Indians (1775) in which he advanced the theory that the Indians were descendants of the Jews.

[Adam].Entry Details: architect and sculptor of the Zeno Maggiore, the Veronese basilica.

Adam, the Brothers.Entry Details: poss. Brooks Adams [1843-1027, son of Charles Francis ADAMS, brother of Henry Brooks Adams, American historian] and Henry Brooks ADAMS, or poss. Robert (1738-92) and James (1730-94) Adam, English architects and designers of furniture in the classical style.

Adams, Charles Francis.Entry Details: 1807-86, son of John Quincy ADAMS, U. S. statesman, minister to Great Britain (1861-68); edited letters of Abigail ADAMS, Works of John ADAMS (10 vol., 1850-56) and Memoirs of John Quincy ADAMS (12 vol, 1874-77).

[Adams, Elihu].Entry Details: brother of John ADAMS, made deputy sheriff of Braintree, Massachusetts, 1761.

[Adams, George Washington].Entry Details: ?1801-28, eldest son of John Quincy ADAMS.

[Adams, Henry].Entry Details: 1646, founder of the Adams family in America, in 1640 he was granted 40 acres at Mt. WOLLASTON, later BRAINTREE, Massachusetts.

[Adams, Henry Brooks].Entry Details: 1838-1918, son of Charles Francis ADAMS; American historian, taught medieval history at Harvard (1870-77).

Adams, John (J., Johnnie).Entry Details: 1735-1826, second President of the U. S. (1796-1800). Delegate to First CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774); appointed commissioner  to France (1777-78) and minister to the United Provinces (1730-82), envoy to Great Britain (1785-88), elected Vice-President (1788, 1792), serving under George Washington.

Adams, John Quincy (J. Q., J. Quincy).Entry Details: 1767-1848, sixth President of the U. S. (1825-29). Son of John ADAMS, member of the U. S Senate (1803-08), minister to Russia (1809-11), member of commission to negotiate the peace after War of 1812, minister to Great Britain (1815), Secretary of State under MONROE (1817-25), after term as President, he served in the House of Representatives (1831-48).

Adams, Joseph.Entry Details: 1626?-94, youngest son of Henry ADAMS, great-grandfather of John ADAMS and Samuel ADAMS.

Adams, Samuel (Sam, Saml).Entry Details: 1722-1803, American patriot Leader of the Massachusetts legislature (1765-74), active at the Boston Tea Party (1773), signer of Declaration of Independence, member of CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-81), governor of Massachusetts (1794-97). A radical, he was among the more extreme spokesmen for independence from England, after the Revolution, his influence declined.

Adams, Thomas.Entry Details: one of the grantees of the first charter of the Colony of Massachusetts Bay (1629), he may have been a relative of Henry ADAMS

Adamses.Entry Details: the ADAMS family in the U. S

Ade du Lesterplatz.Entry Details: pun. (Ger) ade du, (Fr) adieu farewell Leicester Square, from British war song, Tipperary.

Ade du Piccadilly.Entry Details: pun: farewell Piccadilly, see entry above

Adelphi.Entry Details: the Adelphi Hotel, the Strand, London.

Adet.Entry Details: Pierre-Auguste, 1763-1834, French envoy to U. S. (1795) with rank of minister plenipotentiary.

Adonis.Entry Details: a youth loved by APHRODITE; when he was killed by a boar, she caused the anemone to spring from his blood. Adonis is the central figure in a number of fertility rites and myths which celebrate his death and survival, TAMMUZ is the Babylonian equivalent of Adonis. (See Bion, Lament for Adonis; Ovid, Metamorphoses, X).

Ad Orcum autem quisquam? / nondum nave n.Entry Details: (L) But (has) anyone (yet been) to Hell? has not yet come in a black ship. (See: Odyssey, X, 502).

Adrian.Entry Details: Adrian IV, d.1159, the first and only English Pope (1154-59)

[Aeetes].Entry Details: king of Colchis, brother of CIRCE and father of Medea.

Aegesta.Entry Details: town of NW coast of Sicily, said to have been founded by the Trojans, called Egesta or Aegesta by the Greeks, now called Alcamo.

Aegeus.Entry Details: legendary king of Athens, father of THESEUS.

Aeneas.Entry Details: the Trojan, hero of the Aeneid; his descendants were the legendary founders of Rome, son of ANCHISES and APHRODITE.

aere perennius.Entry Details: (L) more enduring than bronze. (See. Horace, Odes, III, 30).

Aethelbert.Entry Details: 616 AD, King of Kent, organized a code of laws based on Roman law and on the code of INA.

affatigandose per suo piacere o no/ non.Entry Details: (It) tiring himself, for his pleasure or not/ he will never need provision. (From a letter of Sigismondo MALATESTA, see Yriarte, Un Condottiere au XVe Siecle, 381).

Agada.Entry Details: locality in African Sudan, now Agadez; first stop of the FASA in the reincarnation of WAGADU. (See. Frobenius and Fox, African Genesis, 97-110).

Agatha.Entry Details: Saint Agatha, 3rd-century Sicilian virgin, martyred by Decius.

agit considerate.Entry Details: (L) he leads with deliberation. (See: A. Lacharme, Confucu Chi-King, III, 3, ode 9, stanza 3).

Agnesina.Entry Details: d. C. 1430, a matron of Modena who, apparently, had committed adultery and poisoned her husband, under the edict (1425) of Niccolo d'ESTE, she was beheaded.

Agresti.Entry Details: Signora Olivia Rossetti Agresti, daughter of William Michael Rossetti; living in Rome, Signora Agresti has for years been writing on 20th-century economic problems.

a guisa de leon. quando S1 posa.Entry Details: (It) as a lion does when he rests (See Purgatorio, 6, 66).

Ahama.Entry Details: (Ahma), d. 1282 AD, minister of KUBLAI KHAN, used his power to enrich himself; alarmed at his excesses, several members of the court, led by OUANG-TCHU, formed a conspiracy and assassinated him.

Ah Monsieur vous allez raser une toile?.Entry Details: (Fr) Ah, Sir, are you going to shave (destroy?) a *canvas ?

Ah, voui, Vive le Ro1.Entry Details: (Fr) Ah, yeah, long live the King.

Ailas e que'm fau miey huelh/ Quar no ve.Entry Details: (Pr) Alas, that my eyes avail me not/ For they see not what I wish (See Sordello, Ailas, e quem fau miey huelh, Cesare de Lollis, Vita e Poesie di Sordello di Goito, 196).

Ainley.Entry Details: poss. a cat, whose name may have been derived from Henry Ainley (1879-1945), British actor. (See. Letters, 336)

A1ul1pata.Entry Details: (Ayuli Palpata), personal name of Emperor GIN-TSONG.

Akers.Entry Details: poss. Vickers, Sons and Co, or Vickers-Maxim Co., British munitions firms.

akouta.Entry Details: (Mongolian) term for chief of the NUTCHE Tartars

Akouta.Entry Details: (Akuta) 1069-1123, chieftain of the KIN Tartars. In 1114 he rebelled from the Léao (Liao) dynasty of the KHITAN Tartars and entered into an agreement with Emperor HOEI-TSONG, he attacked the Léao, and then invaded the Empire, forcing Hoe1-tseng off the throne. The Kin withdrew to Peiping, which they made their capital.

Akra.Entry Details: town on the Atlantic coast of North Africa, founded by HANNO, just south of GUTTA.

A Lady asks me...Entry Details: from Cavalcant1, Donna mi prega. (See. Translations, 132-141).

Albert.Entry Details: Prince Albert, 1819-61, Prince Consort of England, husband of VICTORIA.
Leon Battista, 1404-72, Italian architect, designer of the TEMPIO.

Albigenses.Entry Details: a religious sect of S France in the Middle Ages, although officially designated as Christian heretics, they were adherents of a form of Manichaeism. The Albigenses appeared in the 11th century, in 1208 Innocent III proclaimed the Albigensian Crusade to stamp them out, and, by 1233, the Albigenses were finished.

Albizz1.Entry Details: a Florentine family of the late 14th century, members of the Parte Guelfa.

Alcazar.Entry Details: prob. Alcázar de San Juan, town in Ciudad-Real province, central Spain.

Alcides.Entry Details: error for ATREIDAES. (See: Aeschylus, Agamemnon, I, 3).

Alcmene.Entry Details: the wife of Amphitryon, Zeus loved her and visited her in the shape of her husband; by Zeus she bore HERACLES, by Amphitryon, Iphicles. ODYSSEUS sees her in the underworld. (See Odyssey, XI, 266).

[Aldobrandino, Jgo].Entry Details: 1405-25, bastard son of Niccolo d'ESTE and stepson of Parisina MALATESTA, he and Parisina were beheaded when Niccoló discovered their adultery.

Aletha.Entry Details: prob an invention, a sea deity.

Alexander.Entry Details: Cicely Henrietta, who sat for WHISTLER's Arrangement in Gray and Green.

[Alexander I ].Entry Details: 1777-1825, emperor of Russia (1801-25) during the Napoleonic wars.

Alfonso.Entry Details: Alfonso V (Alfonso the Magnunimous) 1396-1458, King of Aragon and Sicily (1416-58) and of Naples (1443-58). Sigismondo MALATESTA fought for Alfonso against Venice and Florence, but later changed sides.

[Alfonso].Entry Details: character in Lope de Vega's play, Las Almenas de Toro, brother of King SANCHO. (See Spirit of Romance, 191-193).

Algiaptou.Entry Details: prob. AIULIPATA, Emperor GIN-TSONG, who ruled 1311-20 and who did honor to CONFUCIUS by restoring the ceremonies (1313) instituted to honor him.

Alhambra.Entry Details: the famous group of buildings above Granada, Spain.

Alice.Entry Details: poss. Alice of Montpellier, see VENTADOUR, LADY OF.

aliofants.Entry Details: reference is to the elephant motifs in the TEMPIO.

Aliscans.Entry Details: the Alyscamps or Aleschans, necropolis of Arles, France. (See. Inferno, 9, 112).

Alix.Entry Details: Alais Capet, second daughter of LOUIS VII; betrothed to RICHARD I of England, 6 January 1169; in 1191 Richard was released from this agreement and her dowry was returned.

alixantos, aliotrephes, eiskatebaine.Entry Details: (Gr) worn by the sea, feeding in the sea (sea-reared), he went down into. (See: Appendix A).

alla non della.Entry Details: (It) to the, not "of the". (Reference is to the statement in the PROGRAMMA DI VERONA è un diritto alla proprietà, it IS a right to property).

Allegre.Entry Details: poss. Montallegro, a hill above RAPALLO, Italy.

[Almeida, Don Joas Theolomica de].Entry Details: envoy extraordinary of Portugal at the Paris Treaty Conference, 1782

Al poco giorno ed al gran cerchio d'ombr.Entry Details: (It) at the dim daylight and at the large circle of shadow. (See Dante, Canzoniere, Sestina I, 1).

Altaforte.Entry Details: castle in Lemousin, 20 miles NE of Periguex, France. The castle of Bertran de Born. Also poss. reference to Pound's poem, "Sestina: Altaforte, 11 hence, as adverb, loudly, riotously, belligerently.

Althea.Entry Details: reference to the Althea in Lovelace's poem, "To Althea from Prison": And my divine Althea brings / To whisper at the grates; also poss. reference to Althea, mother of MELEAGER, who destroyed him by burning a fated log on her grates.

A Lume Spento.Entry Details: title of Pound's first book of verse, published in Venice, 1908. (It) with tapers quenched; at extinguished light. (See: Purgatorio 3, 132).

Alviano.Entry Details: Ser Bartolomeo d', 1455-1515, a general of the Orsinis, suspected for a time of the murder of Giovanni BORGIA.

à Madame la veuve de M. Henry Schorn/ op.Entry Details: (Fr) to Madame, the widow of M. Henry SCHORN/ (Dut) up near the AGSTERBURG wall in the HOOGSTRAAT.

[Amanullah ].Entry Details: 1892-, emir (1919-26) and king (1926-29) of Afghanistan, called Amanullah Khan, made treaties with Russia and Great Britain at Geneva (1921).

Amari-11.Entry Details: (It) Amaryllis, prob. associated in Pound's mind with a song heard at Salzburg.

a marito subtraxit ipsam / dictum Sordel.Entry Details: (L) she withdrew herself from her husband. . / SORDELLO said to have lain with (her). (See: Rolandini, V, 3 in Chabaneau, Les Biographies des Troubadours, 315).

Ambassador.Entry Details: Refers to the ambassador mentioned in John Adams, Works, III, 392.

Ambassador (french).Entry Details: Refers to Armand Augustin-Louis de CAULAINCOURT, a French ambassador.

Ambassador Manchester.Entry Details: Refers to George MONTAGU, the British ambassador to Venice.

Ambrosiana.Entry Details: Refers to the Ambrosian Library in Milan.

amendment Number XVIII.Entry Details: See EIGHTEENTH AMENDMENT, a prohibition to manufacture, sell, or transport alcoholic beverages in the United States.

America.Entry Details: Refers to America, the continent or the United States in various contexts.

American, the.Entry Details: Refers to Harry S. TRUMAN, the 33rd President of the United States.

American Army.Entry Details: Refers to the American Army of Occupation in Italy in 1945.

American civil war.Entry Details: Refers to the American Civil War, a conflict between the Union and Confederate states in the United States from 1861 to 1865.

American Curia.Entry Details: Prob. the U.S. Congress, the legislative branch of the United States federal government.

[American Indians].Entry Details: Refers to the indigenous peoples of America.

American Legislature.Entry Details: Refers to the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS, the legislative body of the Thirteen Colonies and later the United States from 1774 to 1789.

Ames, Fisher.Entry Details: 1758-1808, member of the House of Representatives (1789-97), supporter of the financial policies of Alexander HAMILTON.

Amherst.Entry Details: Lord Jeffrey, 1717-97, English general, commanded at the capture of Cape Breton from the French (1758), took Ticonderoga (1759), made commander-in-chief of British forces in America (1759).

Amiens.Entry Details: Manufacturing city of Somme department, N France.

ammassi.Entry Details: (It) piles (of things), grain pools. (See. What is Money For?, 13).

Amphion.Entry Details: A musician, so excellent that he drew stones after him with the music of his lyre.

Amphitrite.Entry Details: French ship belonging to BEAUMARCHAIS; carried supplies to the colonists during the Revolutionary War.

Amsterdam.Entry Details: The Dutch city, John ADAMS served there as the American minister to the Netherlands (1780).

Amur.Entry Details: River in NE Asia, forming the boundary between Manchuria and the Chita region and Khabarovsk Territory of the USSR.

Anacreon.Entry Details: Fl. 521 BC, the Greek lyric poet.

Anafeste.Entry Details: Paul Luc, d. 717 AD, early tribune of Venice and first Doge, reputed to have been a just magistrate.

Anastasia.Entry Details: Saint Anastasia, 4th-century Roman noblewoman martyred under DIOCLETIAN.

Anatoth.Entry Details: City of BENJAMIN, home of JEREMIAH.

Anaxiforminges.Entry Details: (Gr) Lords of the lyre. (See: Appendix A).

Ancures.Entry Details: Companion of SANCHO in Lope de Vega's play, Las Almenas de Toro.

\"and all their generation\".Entry Details: From Ford Madox Ford, The Three-Ten.

and belt the citye quahr of nobil fame.Entry Details: From Gavin Douglas, Aeneid. (See: Literary Essays, 245).

Andromeda.Entry Details: A constellation, between Pegasus and Perseus, in the northern skies, represented as a chained woman. and the greatest is charity 74/12 see I Corinthians 13, 13. And then went down to the ship 1/3-5. from Odyssey, XI, 1-104. (See Literary Essays, 259-264). and the pleasure of having it hot:83/112. poss. variation of T. S. Eliot, The Waste Land, II, 167. to get the beauty of it hot.

Angelico.Entry Details: Giovanni da Fiesole, Fra Angelico, 1387-1455, Florentine painter.

Angevins.Entry Details: Members of two medieval dynasties originating in France. Refers to Rene of Anjou, Duke of Anjou (1434) who sought control of Naples and Sicily.

Angold.Entry Details: J. P., 1909-1943, British poet; killed in World War II.

Anjou.Entry Details: Region and former duchy of W France.

Annapolis.Entry Details: Port in Maryland, seat of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1783-84).

Anne, Lady.Entry Details: Prob. Lady Anne Blunt, wife of W. S. BLUNT.

[Anor].Entry Details: Daughter of the Countess of Chatellerault, mother of ELEANOR of Aquitaine.

Anschluss.Entry Details: Political merger of two countries, particularly, the merger (1938) of Austria and Germany.

Antares.Entry Details: The principal star of Scorpio, called Scorpio's Heart.

Anticlea.Entry Details: Wife of Laertes and mother of ODYSSEUS. (See: Odyssey, XI, 84-85, 152-153).

Antille, Nicolo de.Entry Details: Niccolò dell' Antella, Auditore of the BALIA of Siena, 1622.

Antioch.Entry Details: Ancient city on the Orontes, Turkey.

Antis.Entry Details: Anti-Federalists, opposed to the adoption of the U. S. Constitution; followers of Thomas JEFFERSON.

Antoninus.Entry Details: Antoninus Pius, 86-161, Roman Emperor (138-161), administered the empire with ability, kept the peace, and carried out an extensive building program.

Antzar.Entry Details: Antsar, fl 1231, Mongolian general serving under Emperor OGOTAI KHAN during the great Mongol campaigns against the KIN Tartars in Honan province.

Ao1.Entry Details: An expression of uncertain meaning; it occurs 172 times in the Oxford manuscript of the Chanson de Roland, generally following the last line of a laisse. (See T. Atkinson Jenkins' edition of the poem, Boston, 1924, p. 4, for comment).

apaoki.Entry Details: (Mongolian) term for the chief of the KHITAN Tartars.

Aphrodite.Entry Details: The goddess of love, beauty, and fertility. Born of blood and the sea foam (from which comes her name), she was the mother of AENEAS, lover of ADONIS and ANCHISES in the various Greek legends in which she appears. In Cyprus especially she was worshipped, with Adonis, as the goddess of fertility. (See: Homeric HYMN V; see also VENUS).

Apollo.Entry Details: Phoebus Apollo, Olympian god of light, music, prophecy, and pastoral matters.

Aquabello.Entry Details: Enrico Acquadelli, steward to Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Aquinas.Entry Details: Saint Thomas, 1225-74, scholastic philosopher and Doctor of the Church, author of the Summa Theologiae.

Aquitain.Entry Details: Aquitaine, once a duchy and kingdom in SW France, established as kingdom by Charlemagne, it became a duchy under the Counts of Potters; in the late 9th century, it came under the control of William, count of Auvergne. The marriage of ELEANOR of Aquitaine to HENRY II of England gave England claim to Aquitaine and led to the Hundred Years War.

Arabia Petra.Entry Details: Arabia Petraea (Rocky Arabia), the NW part of Arabia, including the Sinai Peninsula; not part of modern Arabia.

Arachne.Entry Details: The girl who challenged ATHENA to a weaving contest because the girl dared to contest the gods. Athena changed her into a spider, so she should weave forever; hence, a spider.

Aragon.Entry Details: The medieval kingdom in N Iberian peninsula.

Arambo.Entry Details: Arambys, a town on the Atlantic coast of N Africa, founded by HANNO, just south of MELI.

Arbia.Entry Details: River in the vicinity of Siena.

Archbishop of Morea Lower.Entry Details: Orthodox delegate to the Council of Ferrara-Florence (1438-45). (See: MOREA).

Archbishop of Sardis.Entry Details: Orthodox delegate to the Council of Ferrara-Florence (1438-45). (See: SARDIS).

Archbishops of Athens, Corinth and of Tr.Entry Details: Orthodox delegates to the Council of Ferrara-Florence (1438-45). (See. ATHENS, CORINTH, TREBIZOND).

Archivio Storico La Guerra der Senesi co.Entry Details: (It) Historical Archives The War of the Sienese against the Count of PITIGLIANO.

Arcturus.Entry Details: Chief star of the constellation Boötes.

Arezzo, Gul d'.Entry Details: Guido d'Arezzo, ?995-1050? Benedictine monk and musician, supposed to be the inventor of the medieval "great scale" or gamut, the hexacord, and hexacord solmization.

Armenonville.Entry Details: Pavillon d'Armenonville, fashionable restaurant in the Bois de Boulogne, Paris.

Armour.Entry Details: Chicago meatpacking firm, among those investigated by Upton Sinclair for his novel, The Jungle (1906).

Arnold.Entry Details: Benedict, 1741-1801, American army officer and traitor; in the Revolutionary War, he received the rank of brigadier general in the Continental Army. In 1779, he began correspondence with the British forces and in 1780, while he commanded West Point, he arranged for the surrender of the fort to the British. The plot was discovered, and Arnold fled to British protection.

Arrarat.Entry Details: Mount Ararat in Turkey, identified as the landing place of Noah's Ark.

Artemis.Entry Details: The goddess of wildlife and the hunt. See ACTAEON.

\"a S. Bartolomeo m1 vidi col pargoletto.Entry Details: (It) "At St. Bartholomeo I found myself with the little boy/ nailed to the ground with his arms spread/ as on the cross, (you) groaned/ I said: I am the moon. "/ With my feet on the silvery scythe/ he looked pitiful to me.

Ascension.Entry Details: Ascension Day, fortieth day after Easter.

a schavezo.Entry Details: (It) a scavezzo: quickly, hurriedly, at wholesale price.

Asquith.Entry Details: Herbert Henry Asquith, 1st Earl of Oxford and Asquith, 1852-1928, British statesman; Prime Minister (1908-16).

[Asquith, Margot].Entry Details: 1864-1945, second wife of Herbert Henry ASQUITH.

assez mal propre.Entry Details: (Fr) rather slovenly. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, XI, 113, note).

Assisi.Entry Details: Town in Umbria, central Italy; birthplace of St. Francis of Assisi; above the Saint's tomb, two Gothic churches were built, both decorated with frescoes by Cimabue, Giotto, and others.

Astafieva.Entry Details: Serafima Astafieva, 1876-1934, Russian dancer and teacher, member of the corps de ballet of the Maryinsky Theatre (1895-1905) and of the Diaghilev Company (1909-1911), opened a ballet school in London.

Astor.Entry Details: John Jacob Astor, 1763-1848, American merchant and fur trader.

Astorga.Entry Details: Town in León province, NW Spain.

atasal.Entry Details: The word is said to mean "union with God" and to come from the writings of Avicenna, the Mohammedan physician and philosopher.

Athame.Entry Details: Prob. inv.: a daughter of the Sun. (See: PHAETHUSA).

Athelstan.Entry Details: AEthelstan, d.940, king of the English (924-40).

Athena.Entry Details: The goddess of wisdom, Pallas Athena; patron of the arts of peace and of war; guardian of cities, especially of ATHENS.

A tiels leis en ancien scripture.Entry Details: (Pr) according to such laws (Fr) in old handwriting.

Atreus.Entry Details: King of Mycenae, son of Pelops, who brought a curse on his house. Thyestes, Atreus' brother, seduced Atreus' wife, Atreus murdered three of the four sons of Thyestes and served them to their father. Thyestes laid a curse on the house of Atreus, which descended upon his sons, Agamemnon, Menelaus.

Atthis.Entry Details: Possibly one of the young girls of whom SAPPHO sang, probably Attis, a priest of Cybele, who castrated himself in a fit of religious fanaticism. (See. Catullus, LXIII).

Atti, Antonio degli.Entry Details: Fl. 1448, brother of Isotta degli ATTI.

Atti, Isotta degli.Entry Details: 1430-1470, first the mistress, then the third wife (1456) of Sigismondo MALATESTA. She bore him at least two sons, both illegitimate SALLUSTIO (b. 1448) and Valerien (b. 1454). It was in her honor that Malatesta built the TEMPIO.

Attlee.Entry Details: Clement Richard Attlee, 1883-, British statesman; leader of the Labor Party, Prime Minister (1945-51).

Aubeterre.Entry Details: A church just outside Potters, France.

Auchmuty.Entry Details: Robert Auchmuty, d. 1788, colonial jurist and loyalist, appointed judge of the vice-admiralty for Massachusetts and New Hampshire. With John ADAMS, he was counsel for Captain PRESTON in the case of the Boston Massacre (1770). He returned to England in 1776.

Au douce temps de pascor.Entry Details: (Fr) in the fair Eastertime (See: Jo1os of Tolosa Lautrier el dous temps de pascor).

augean stables.Entry Details: The stables of Augeas, king of Elis, cleansed by HERACLES.

Augusta.Entry Details: One of the three principal characters in Rene CREVEL's Les Pieds dans le plat (1933), where she is an Austrian archduchess.

Augustus.Entry Details: BC 63-14 AD, first Roman emperor (BC 27-14 AD).

Aula regum.Entry Details: Aula Regis, the chief court of England during early Norman times. The single court split into four parts: the High Court of Chancery, the Queen's Bench, the Exchequer, and the Court of Common Pleas.

aulentissima rosa fresca.Entry Details: (It) thou sweetly-smelling fresh red rose. (See: Ciullo d'Alcamo, Dialogue, the first line of which runs: Rosa fresca aulentissima).

Aunt F..Entry Details: Aunt Frank, great aunt (by marriage) of Ezra Pound, she took him to Europe when he was a child.

Aurelia.Entry Details: The Aurelian Way (Via Aurelia), the Roman highway which runs along the coast to Pisa and then north to Genoa.

Aurunculeia.Entry Details: Vinia Aurunculeia, a bride praised by Catullus. (See: Catullus, LXI).

Austini, Marcellus.Entry Details: Prob. member of the Sienese BALÍA, 1622.

Authority comes from right reason.Entry Details: From Johannes Scotus ERIGENA, De Divisione Naturae, I, chapter 69.

Auvergne.Entry Details: A section of Provence, SE central France.

Auxerre.Entry Details: Capital of Yonne department, NE central France.

avenément révolution allemande posait de.Entry Details: (Fr) Beginning German revolution posed some new problems, / commercial routine to be replaced by the creation of two/ funds (of) gold and wheat destined to the victorious (German) proletariat.

Avernus.Entry Details: Lake near Cumae and Naples, close to it was the cave by which AENEAS descended to the lower world, sometimes, as here, used as the name of the lower world itself.

Avignon.Entry Details: Capital of Vaucluse department, SE France, on the left bank of the Rhone, was the Papal See during the 'Babylonian Captivity' (1309-78) and residence of several antipopes during the Great Schism (1378-1408), under Papal rule, it became a great trading city.

avoyer.Entry Details: (Fr) Chief magistrate of a free city or a canton in French Switzerland.

Awol.Entry Details: The Lady Aw01, first wife of GENJI in Lady Murasaki's Tale of Genji. Also: character in the Noh play, Awoi no Uye. (See. Translations, 323-331).

[Ayen, la Duchesse d'].Entry Details: Prob. Henriette-Anne-Louse d'Aguesseau de Fresne, Duchesse d'Ayen, wife of Jean-Paul-François de NOAILLES.

Ayers, Severn.Entry Details: Member of the Virginia House of Burgesses in 1770.

Ayliffe.Entry Details: John, 1676-1732, English jurist and writer on law.

Azeglio.Entry Details: Massimo Taparelli, the Marchesse d'Azeglio, 1798-1866, Italian statesman and author, leader in the Risorgimento (1848); assisted early liberal reforms of PIUS IX, with whom he joined in support of the House of Savoy.

Bach, Johnnie.Entry Details: Johann Sebastian, 1685-1750, the German organist and composer.

Bacher.Entry Details: Prob pseudonym for an inhabitant of Gais, near Brunico, in the Italian Tyrol.

Bacon, Baldy.Entry Details: Francis S. Bacon, fl. 1910, American businessman.

Bacon, Lord.Entry Details: Sir Francis, 1st Baron Verulam, 1561-1626, English philosopher and statesman.

Baghdad.Entry Details: City in Iraq, on the Tigris river. The Germans once projected a railroad from Berlin to Baghdad.

Bagni Romagna.Entry Details: Bagno di Romagna, commune in Forli province, N Italy.

Bagot.Entry Details: Sir Charles, 1781-1843, British diplomat, minister to the U.S. (1815-20) when he negotiated the Rush-Bagot Convention (1817) limiting armaments on the Great Lakes.

Bahai, Sir Abdul Baha.Entry Details: 1844-1921, leader of the religion known as Bahaism, founded by his father Baha Ullah. Bahaists believe in the unity of all religions, universal education, world peace, and the equality of sexes.

baily.Entry Details: Bail, the outer wall of a feudal castle, or the court thereby enclosed.

Baker.Entry Details: George Fisher, 1840-1931, American financier and philanthropist, one of the founders (1863) of the First National Bank of New York, president of the bank in 1877, chairman of its board of directors in 1909, he was closely associated with the house of MORGAN.

Balfour.Entry Details: Arthur James, 1848-1930, British statesman; foreign minister (1916-1919), author of the Balfour Declaration which pledged British support to the founding of a Jewish state in Palestine.

Balia.Entry Details: (It) authority, power, bench of magistrates, here the reference is to the Balia, ruling authority of SIENA in the early 17th century.

Baluba.Entry Details: Name of a tribe (and of the place of residence) in the upper valley of the Kassai river, a tributary of the Congo, in the SW Belgian Congo.

banco di giro.Entry Details: (It) a bank specializing in the endorsement and transfer of credit.

Bancroft.Entry Details: Edward, 1744-1821, American scientist and secret agent; during the American Revolution he served as a secret agent for the American commissioners in Paris, it was alleged that he sold information to the British government.

Bandini.Entry Details: Poss. Carlo Bandini, author of Roma e la nobilita romana nel tramonto del secolo XVIII (1914).

Bank.Entry Details: See SECOND NATIONAL BANK OF THE UNITED STATES.

Bankers.Entry Details: Corporal in the Provost section, DTC, Pisa.

Bankhead.Entry Details: John Hollis, 1872-1946, U. S. Senator from Alabama (1930-46).

Bank of England.Entry Details: Founded 1694 by William PATERSON; the central bank of England.

Bank of the Paris Union.Entry Details: La Banque de l'Union Parisienne, an investment bank founded in 1874 and reorganized in 1904; controlled by ZAHAROFF and SCHNEIDER-CREUSOT.

Baptist learnery.Entry Details: Poss. Baylor University, Waco, Texas, a Baptist school.

Barabbas.Entry Details: The bandit held in jail at the time of the arrest of Christ.

Barabello.Entry Details: A poetaster of the time of Pope Leo X; he asked to be crowned with laurel in the Capitol; during the mock ceremony, the Pope's elephant, on which Barabello was riding, became frightened by the fireworks and refused to move.

Barbary.Entry Details: The Barbary States, North Africa. In the Algerine War (1815), the U. S. forced concessions from the dey of Algiers.

Barbier de Séville.Entry Details: The play by BEAUMARCHAIS, first performed in 1775.

Bariatinsky, Princess.Entry Details: Prob. Lydia YAVORSKA, 1874-1921, wife of Prince Vladamir Bariatinsky; poss. Princess Anatole Marie Bariatinsky, author of My Russian Life (1923).

Barilli.Entry Details: Bruno, 1880-1952, Italian music critic and composer.

Barlow.Entry Details: Joel, 1754-1812, American writer and diplomat; appointed U. S. consul to Algiers (1795); he succeeded in releasing American prisoners and negotiating treaties with Algiers. In 1811, he was sent to Europe to negotiate a commercial treaty with Napoleon.

Barre, Mass.Entry Details: Town in central Massachusetts, NW of Worcester.

Bartok.Entry Details: Bela, 1881-1945, Hungarian composer, pianist and collector of folk music.

Basinio.Entry Details: Basinio de Basann, 1425-1457, Italian poet patronized by Sigismondo MALATESTA, wrote L'Isottaeus, a poem modeled after Ovid's Heroides, which represents Sigismondo's love for Isotta degli ATTI (Paris: 1539). In 1456, Basinio defeated Parcelio PANDONE in a literary debate, Pandone argued for the thesis 'One may be an elegant Latin poet without having studied assiduously the Greek authors.'

Basse Cour.Entry Details: The house in Passy, formerly the Hotel de Valentinois, donated to the American ministers (1778) by Donatien le Ray de CHAUMONT.

Batavia.Entry Details: City on NW coast of Java.

Bathsheba.Entry Details: Wife of Uriah, the Hittite. David seduced her, had her husband killed, and then married her out of remorse. She was the mother of Solomon.

battistero.Entry Details: (It) baptistery, text reference is evidently to that of Pisa.

Battle Hymn of the Republic.Entry Details: The famous marching song of the American Civil War, written in 1861 by Julia Ward Howe.

Battle of Lexington.Entry Details: See LEXINGTON AND CONCORD, Battles of.

Battle of Waffenschlag.Entry Details: Inv., note: waffe = (Ger) weapon + schlag = (Ger) strike.

Baur, Wilhelm.Entry Details: 1826-97, author of Geschichte und Lebensbilder aus der Erneuerung des Religiösen Lebens in Deutschen Befreiungskriegen, Hamburg, 1864. (See: IN DEN DEUTSCHEN BEFREUDENSKRIEGEN).

Bayard.Entry Details: James Asheton, 1767-1815, American statesman, member of the House of Representatives (1797-1803), U. S. Senate (1804-13), and of the commission which negotiated the Treaty of Ghent (1814), ending the War of 1812.
John Bukenheim, 1738-1807, Philadelphia merchant; colonel in the Philadelphia Volunteers during the Revolution; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1785-87).

Beardsley, Aubrey.Entry Details: Aubrey Vincent, 1872-98, English illustrator and writer.

Bearing the golden bough of Argicida.Page Numbers: from Homeric Hymn V, To Aphrodite, 117-118
Bearing the golden bough of Argicida.Entry Details: (Prob. a translation from the Latin version of Georgius Dartona Cretensis).

Beauchamps.Entry Details: Richard de Beauchamp, ? 1430-81, Bishop of Hereford and Salisbury, Chancellor of the Order of the Garter.

Beaugency.Entry Details: Town in Loiret department, on the Loire river, France. There is an old French song which runs: Orléans, Beaugency! Notre Dame de Cléry! Vendôme! Vendôme! Quel chagrin, quel ennu De compter toute la nuit Les heures -- les heures!

Beaumarchais.Entry Details: Pierre Augustin Caron de, 1732-99, French playwright and man of affairs.

Beauties of Mougden.Entry Details: The Eulogy on MUKDEN, a poem written by Emperor KIEN-LONG in 1743 after a visit to Mukden to honor the tomb of his ancestors.

Beauvais.Entry Details: Capital of Oise department, N France.

Beccaria.Entry Details: Cesare Bolnesana di, ?1735-1794?, Italian economist and jurist, author of Tratto dei Delitti e della Pene (1764).

Becket.Entry Details: Thomas à Becket, 1117-70, Archbishop of Canterbury (1162-70); murdered by the agents of Henry II.

Bedell.Entry Details: Lieutenant in the Provost section, DTC, Pisa.

Beebe.Entry Details: William, 1877-, American scientist, explorer and author, famous for his underwater explorations in the bathysphere.

Beecher.Entry Details: Henry Ward, 1813-87, American Congregational preacher, orator and lecturer, held the pulpit of the Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, New York, from 1847; leader in the Abolitionist movement.

Be glad, poor beaste.Entry Details: poss. variation on Chaucer, Balade de Bon Conseyl, translated by Henry Van Dyke in SPEARE, Pocket Book of Verse: Therefore, poor beaste

Bekford.Entry Details: William Beckford, 1709-1770, West Indian planter; member of Parliament; alderman and Lord Mayor of London.

Belcher, Governor.Entry Details: Jonathan, 1682-1757, colonial governor of Massachusetts and New Hampshire (1730-41); governor of New Jersey (1747-57).

Bel Fiore.Entry Details: Belriguardo, a villa of Borso d'ESTE.

Bell, Miss.Entry Details: Gertrude Margaret Lowthian Bell, 1868-1926, British authority on, and government servant in, the Near East.

Bella, Piero della.Entry Details: Officer in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA. (Note: Pound's description: that gay bird is a misreading of his source, which describes Piero della Bella as a gagliardo, or brave, valiant. See: Tonini, Rimini nella Signoria de' Malatesti, II, 281, who quotes Pound's source, the Cronaca of Gaspare Broglio, an unpublished manuscript in the Gambalunga Library, Rimini).

Belle Poule.Entry Details: A French frigate anchored at Corunna, John ADAMS dined aboard 24 December 1779.

Bellini, Giovanni.Entry Details: 1426-1516, leading painter of the Venetian school, noted for his altarpieces and Madonnas.

Belotti.Entry Details: Owner of Belotti's Ristorante Italiano, 12 Old Compton Street, London, where Pound and his friends dined, 1910-1920.

Belmont.Entry Details: August, 1816-1890, American banker and politician; head of August Belmont and Company.

bel seno (in rimas escarsas, vide sopra).Entry Details: (It) beautiful bosom (Pr) (in rare rimes, (It) see above).

Benette joue la Valse des Elfes.Entry Details: (Fr) Benette plays the Waltz of the Elves. (See Francis Jammes, Le Poète).

Bengal.Entry Details: A region in South Asia, now part of India and Bangladesh.

Ben.Entry Details: Prob. Benjamin FRANKLIN, poss Benito MUSSOLINI.

Benjamin.Entry Details: The plateau of E central Palestine, near the Jordan river, between Jerusalem and Bethel.

Bentinck, Colonel.Entry Details: Berend Henrik, 1753-1830, one of the Dutch negotiators of the Treaty of Paris (1783).

Bentinck.Entry Details: Lord William Cavendish, 1774-1839, British statesman and soldier; governor-general of Madras, India (1803-07); commander in Sicily (1811); governor-general of India (1833).

Benzi, Andreas.Entry Details: Andrea, fl. 1460, a fiscal agent of Pope PIUS II, delivered the papal accusation against Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Benzo, Nic.Entry Details: Officer in the household squadron of the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Berdsma.Entry Details: Bergsma, fl. 1780, an official of the Province of Friesland.

Berlitz.Entry Details: The school of language studies, founded by Maximilian Delphinus Berlitz, 1852-1921.

Bernard.Entry Details: Sir Francis, 1712-79, colonial governor of New Jersey (1758-60), and Massachusetts (1760-69). His policies aroused bitter opposition and he was removed from office in 1769 and returned to England.

Bersolle.Entry Details: Fl. 1778, a Frenchman engaged in the repair of ships.

Bessedovsky.Entry Details: Grigoril Zinovevich, a former Soviet diplomat, author of Revelations of a Soviet Diplomat (1931).

Betuene April and Merche.Entry Details: From the 14th-century lyric Alysoun 'Bytuene Mersh and Averil/ When spray beginneth to spring.'

Beveridge, Senator.Entry Details: Albert Jeremiah, 1862-1927, U. S. Senator (1899-1911) and historian, supported the policies of Theodore Roosevelt, an organizer of the Progressive Party (1912).

bezant.Entry Details: Gold coin issued by the Byzantine emperors, circulating in Europe between 6th and 15th centuries.

Bicker.Entry Details: H, fl. 1780, a Dutch statesman, friendly to the American Revolutionary cause.

Biddle, Nicholas.Entry Details: 1786-1844, American financier; appointed director of the SECOND NATIONAL BANK OF THE UNITED STATES (1819) and became its president (1822). He was President JACKSON's chief antagonist in the Bank War.

Bill of Rights.Entry Details: The British Bill of Rights, drawn up in 1689.

Bimmy.Entry Details: An invented name with no particular reference.

Bingen.Entry Details: City in W Germany, located on the Rhine above the whirlpool known as the Binger Lock.

Bingen on the Rhine.Entry Details: A poem by Caroline Elizabeth Sarah Norton.

Bingham.Entry Details: William, 1752-1804, American politician; founder of the Bank of North America (1781), U. S. Senator (1795-1801).

Binyon.Entry Details: Laurence, 1869-1943, English poet, Keeper of the Prints and Drawings, British Museum, authority on Oriental art, translator of DANTE.

Birrell.Entry Details: Augustine, 1850-1933, English essayist and public official.

Bishop.Entry Details: Possibly Samuel Wilberforce, 1804-1873, Bishop of Oxford and of Winchester, in 1860 Wilberforce attacked the Darwinian theory and was challenged and defeated in argument by T. H. Huxley.

Bishops of Lacedaemon and of Mitylene, /.Entry Details: All Orthodox delegates to the Council of Ferrara-Florence (1438-45). (See LACEDAEMON, MYTILENE, RHODES, MODON BRANDOS).

Bishops of Lampascus and Cyprus.Entry Details: Orthodox delegates to the Council of Ferrara-Florence (1438-45). (See LAMPASCUS, CYPRUS).

Bismarck.Entry Details: Otto von, 1815-98, the German soldier and statesman.

Bithynia.Entry Details: Bythnia, ancient country of NW Asia Minor, became a Roman province in BC 74 when Nicodemus willed his kingdom to Rome.

Bivar.Entry Details: Village in Old Castile, near BURGOS, N Spain.

Blake.Entry Details: William, 1757-1827, English mystic poet and illustrator.

Blaydon.Entry Details: Colonel Bladen, fl. 1740, member of the British Board of Trade and Plantations.

Blitterswyk, Baron de Lynden de.Entry Details: Fl. 1782, deputy from ZEELAND at the Conference of Paris.

Blodgett.Entry Details: Possibly Lorin Blodget, author of The Textile Industries of Philadelphia (1880).

Blount.Entry Details: William, 1749-1800, American political leader, U. S. Senator from Tennessee (1796-97), expelled from the Senate on the charge of plotting to aid the British to get control of Spanish Florida and Louisiana.

Blum.Entry Details: Léon, 1872-1950, the French Socialist statesman and writer.

Blunt.Entry Details: Wilfrid Scawen, 1840-1922, English poet and political writer; admired for his independence of mind.

Board of War.Entry Details: A special council established during the American Revolution, acting as an intermediary between the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS and the armed forces.

Boeotians.Entry Details: People of the ancient republic of Boeotia, E central Greece.

Bohlem und Halbach.Entry Details: See Gustave KRUPP VON BOHLEN UND HALBACH.

Bois de Boulogne.Entry Details: A large park containing the racetracks of Longchamp and Auteuil, just W of Paris.

bojar.Entry Details: (Russ) Member of a Russian aristocratic order, favored with certain exclusive privileges.

Boleyn.Entry Details: Anne, ?1507-1536, second wife of Henry VIII and mother of Queen Elizabeth I, she was beheaded, also the Boleyn family.

Bolgarini, Paris.Entry Details: Possibly Sienese representative at the negotiations leading to the establishment of the MONTE DEI PASCHI.

Bolingbroke.Entry Details: Henry St. John, Viscount Bolingbroke, 1678-1754, English statesman and orator, author of Idea of a Patriot King (1749).

Bologna.Entry Details: The city in N central Italy.

Bologna, Francesco da.Entry Details: A printer of whom little is known, possibly he is the same as Francesco Griffi, who was a printer in BOLOGNA in 1516-17.

Bolsano.Entry Details: Bolzano, capital of Bolzano province, N Italy.

bolsheviki.Entry Details: Members of the majority group of the Russian political group led by Lenin, the Workers Social Democratic Party (1903).

Bonaparte, Maria Anna Elisa.Entry Details: 1777-1820, sister of NAPOLEON, made Grand Duchess of Tuscany (1809); exiled 1810.

Bond St..Entry Details: A street in LONDON noted for its fashionable shops.

Bonius.Entry Details: A soldier from Treviso with whom Cunizza da ROMANO took up after SORDELLO had left her.

Book of the Council Major.Entry Details: The records of the Great Council of Venice.

Book of the Mandates.Entry Details: The mandates of the ESTE family.

Boracchios, Los.Entry Details: Los Borrachos, a painting by VELÁSQUEZ in the Prado, Madrid.

Borah.Entry Details: William Edgar, 1865-1940, U. S. Senator (1907-40) a leading spokesman on international affairs.

Bordeaux.Entry Details: Port city of Gironde department, SW France.

Borgia, Caesare.Entry Details: 1476-1507, Italian nobleman; son of Pope Borgia, Giovanni (John)-5/18, 19- d 1497, son of Pope ALEXANDER VI, brother of Caesare BORGIA. His body was found in the Tiber, it was generally held that Caesare instigated his murder.

Borgia, Lucretia.Entry Details: 1480-1519, sister of Caesare BORGIA, daughter of Pope ALEXANDER VI.

Borr.Entry Details: Prob. a surname, reminding Pound of Bertran de Born of ALTAFORTE.

Boston, the.Entry Details: The frigate that carried John ADAMS to his post as commissioner to France in 1778.

Boston Gazette.Entry Details: A Boston newspaper, published 1719-98, the paper was strongly in favor of the American Revolution.

Bourbon.Entry Details: Royal family of France, branches of which ruled Spain, Sicily and Parma at various times.

Bourbon, Mlle.Entry Details: A member of the BOURBON family, living at VERSAILLES in 1783.

Bourrienne.Entry Details: Louis Antoine Fauvelet de, 1769-1834, French diplomat and writer, he was private secretary to NAPOLEON (1797-1802); his memoirs (10 vol., 1829) give a somewhat inaccurate account of Napoleon.

Boutwell.Entry Details: George Sewall, 1818-1905, American politician; member of House of Representatives (1863-69), one of the leaders in the move to impeach President JACKSON; Secretary of the Treasury (1869-73), during which term he averted the attempt to corner the gold market on Black Friday (24 September 1869) by releasing government gold.

Bouvet.Entry Details: Joachim, fl. 1732, Jesuit missionary in China. With GERBILLON and four other Jesuits, he arrived in Peiping in 1688. Bouvet and Gerbillon were made professors of mathematics by KANG-HI and translated several TARTAR works on mathematics into Chinese. He also served as a surveyor and cartographer in the Chinese provinces.

Bowdoin.Entry Details: James, 1726-90, American statesman; nominated to the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774), he was too ill to serve; he became a leading figure in the Massachusetts councils during the American Revolution and became governor of the state in 1785.

Bowers.Entry Details: Claude Gernade, 1878 - American journalist, historian, and diplomat, ambassador to Spain (1933-39).

Bowery, the.Entry Details: Section of lower MANHATTAN, New York, famous for its bars and its derelicts.

Bowring.Entry Details: Sir John, 1792-1872, English statesman and linguist. In 1836 he went to Italy to study England's commercial relations with Tuscany, Lucca, the Lombardian and Papal states. He returned to Italy in 1860 to discuss trade relations with Cavour.

Bracelonde.Entry Details: Possibly Brocéliande, the forest mentioned in the Arthurian legends.

Bracken.Entry Details: Brendan, 1901 - , British publisher, and politician, Minister of Information (1941-45).

Brackett.Entry Details: Brackett's Tavern, The Cromwell Head Inn, Boston.

Bracton.Entry Details: Henry de Bracton (or Bretton), d. 1267, English jurist; author of the first systematic treatise of law in England, De Legibus et Consuetudinibus Angliae.

Braddock.Entry Details: Edward, 1695-1775, commander-in-chief of British forces in America (1754).

Brady, James Buchanan.Entry Details: 1856-1917, American financier, commonly known as Diamond JIM.

Braganza.Entry Details: Capital of Bragança district, NE Portugal, seat of the house of Bragança, former rulers of Portugal.

Braintree.Entry Details: Town in Massachusetts (now QUINCY), home of the ADAMS family, incorporated (1640).

Braintree House.Entry Details: A reference to the ADAMS family, whose home was in BRAINTREE, Mass.

Brandolino, Cetho.Entry Details: Cecco Brandolino, a captain serving in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Brattle.Entry Details: William, 1702-76, brigadier-general in the Massachusetts militia. In 1773 John ADAMS and William Brattle engaged in a debate, published in the Boston newspapers; their remarks, collected under the title The Independence of the Judiciary, appear in the Works of John Adams, III. A loyalist, Brattle went to England during the Revolution.

Brattle Street.Entry Details: A street in BOSTON, Mass., on which John and Abigail ADAMS lived (1768).

Braxton, Carter.Entry Details: 1736-97, American statesman, Virginia delegate to the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS.

Brescia.Entry Details: The capital of Brescia province, N Italy.

Brest-Litovsk.Entry Details: A town in Russia where the treaty between Germany and the BOLSHEVIKI was signed (March 1918).

Brisset.Entry Details: Jean-Pierre, French philologist, and writer. Among his works is Les Origines humaines, deuxième édition de la science de Dieu (1913) in which he "demonstrated" that man is descended from the frog.

Bristol.Entry Details: Port city, Gloucestershire, England, an important center of trade with colonial America.

British constitution.Entry Details: A flexible constitution contained implicitly in the body of common and statutory law of the realm.

British Statutes.Entry Details: Probably State Trials and Statutes at Large, edited by John Selden.

brits.Entry Details: Slang term for the British people.

Britten.Entry Details: John le Britton (or Breton), d. 1275, Bishop of Hereford; author of the treatise on English law, Britton.

Broglie.Entry Details: Victor-François, le Comte de, 1718-1804, Marshal of France (1759), Minister of War (1789).

Brogl108/32.Entry Details: Gaspare, soldier in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA; author of Cronaca, an account of Malatesta's campaigns and life in RIMINI, the manuscript of which is at the Gambalunga Library, Rimini.

Bromley, Joe.Entry Details: Probably an acquaintance of Pound in Philadelphia, C. 1908.

Bronzino.Entry Details: Il Bronzino (Agnolo di Cosimo), 1502-72, Florentine painter in the court of Cosimo I.

Brookhart.Entry Details: Smith Wildman, 1869-1950, U.S. Senator from Iowa, (1928-32), spokesman for farm interests.

Brother Percy.Entry Details: Probably Percy Bysshe SHELLEY; possibly Lord Algernon PERCY.

Browning, Robert.Entry Details: 1812-89, English poet, author of Sordello (1840), etc.

Bruge.Entry Details: Bruges, capital of W Flanders, NW Belgium, once a great trading city.

Brumaire.Entry Details: One of the French Revolutionary months, running between 22 October and 20 November.

Brunik.Entry Details: Town in the Tyrol, N Italy.

Brutus.Entry Details: Marcus Junius, ?78-42 BC, one of the principals in the murder plot against Julius Caesar.

Buardino of Brescia.Entry Details: Sovardino da Brescia, soldier in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Buchanan.Entry Details: James, 1791-1868, President of the U. S. (1857-61).

Buchio.Entry Details: Locality in central Italy taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

[Bucintoro].Entry Details: Originally the special ship used by the Doge of Venice during the ceremony of the marriage of Venice to the Adriatic, now the name of a Venetian rowing club.

Buddha.Entry Details: Direct or indirect references to the Buddha, fl. BC 563-483, who, born of a noble family, renounced luxury and became a hermit at the age of 29. While sitting under a bo (i.e., pipal) tree, he received the "great enlightenment" and became a teacher. Buddhism teaches that suffering is inherent in life and that the greatest good is release from life and suffering through the attainment of nirvana, a state of nonexistence in which the individual loses all sense of self and becomes identified with the Oneness of being.

Buffon.Entry Details: Comte Georges Louis Leclerc de, 1707-88, the French naturalist.

[Bukhara].Entry Details: City in W Uzbek S. S. R., once a center of Moslem worship.

Bulagaio.Entry Details: Probably an acquaintance of Pound in Venice.

Bull.Entry Details: William, 1710-91, colonial Lt. Governor of South Carolina (1760-75).

Bullier.Entry Details: The Bal Bullier, a dance hall on the Boulevard Saint-Michel, Paris.

[Bulwer-Lytton].Entry Details: Edward Robert, 1st Earl of Lytton, 1831-91, English diplomat, and poet.

Bunting.Entry Details: Basil, 20th-century British poet who lived in the Near East; author of Redimiculum Matellarum (1930), Poems (1951).

Buovilla.Entry Details: Possibly residence of William of Buovilla, a noble of Gascony whose wife was loved by Arnaut DANIEL.

bureaucrat paisable, Van Tzin Vei se mon.Entry Details: (Fr) A peaceful bureaucrat, VAN TZIN VEI showed himself, completely incapable of assuming the role of chief of a bloody revolution.

Burgh.Entry Details: Hubert, d. 1243, earl of Kent, chief justice of England under Henry III (1216).

Burgos.Entry Details: Capital of Burgos province, N Spain, in Old Castile, home and burial place of the CID.

Burgundy.Entry Details: Province in E France, divided into the departments of Yonne, Côte d'Ore, Saône-et-Loire, and Ain.

Burke.Entry Details: Edmund, 1729-97, the British statesman and writer, one of the prominent Whigs under GEORGE III; favored liberal treatment of American colonies.

Burne-Jones.Entry Details: Sir Edward, 1833-98, English painter and decorator, strongly influenced by the ROSSETTIS, exponent of Pre-Raphaelite doctrines.

Burnet.Entry Details: Sir Thomas, ?1694-1753, English judge, and political writer.

Burr.Entry Details: Aaron, 1756-1836, American Revolutionary officer and political leader, U. S. Senator (1791-97), ran for President (1800) and received the same number of electoral votes as JEFFERSON; the election was thrown into the Congress, and Burr withdrew from the race to become Vice-President under Jefferson. He was tried for treason after conspiring to seize territory from Spanish America to form a new republic in the Southwest, but was acquitted (1807).

Bushnell.Entry Details: David, ?1742-1824, American inventor, noted for his invention of a submarine.

Buxtehude.Entry Details: Dietrich, 1637-1707, the North German composer, and organist.

Byers.Entry Details: Probably an acquaintance of Pound in Philadelphia, C. 1908.

Byles.Entry Details: Mather, 1707-88, American Congregationalist clergyman, and writer of light verse.

Byzantium.Entry Details: Ancient city on the Bosphorus; site of modern Istanbul.

C, Monsieur.Entry Details: Possibly Paul Claudel, 1868-1955, French poet, and diplomat.

Cabestan.Entry Details: Guillem da Cabestanh, a late 12th-century Provençal troubadour, because he loved Marguerite (or Triclime or Soremonda), wife of Raymond of Chateau Roussillon, Raymond killed Guillem and had his heart cooked and served to Marguerite, upon learning what she had eaten, Marguerite declared that since she had eaten such noble food, her lips should touch no other and threw herself out the window. Some versions of the story claim she stabbed herself; others that she starved herself to death.

Cabot.Entry Details: George, 1752-1823, American businessman and politician, U. S. Senator from Massachusetts (1791-96).

Cabot, J..Entry Details: John Cabot, ?1451-1498?, Venetian explorer; sailing under the English flag, he discovered areas of North America.

Cade, Jack.Entry Details: Died in 1450, English rebel leader of the Kentish rebellion (May-June, 1450) in protest against corruption in the court.

Cadmus.Entry Details: The founder of THEBES; a dragon guarding a spring killed the companions of Cadmus, and he in turn killed the dragon. By ATHENA's instruction, he sowed the dragon's teeth, and from them armed warriors sprang up, these were set fighting each other until only five remained, the Sparti, ancestors of the noble families of Thebes. Cadmus is said to have civilized the BOEOTIANS and to have taught them the use of letters. He was the grandfather of PENTHEUS.

Cadore.Entry Details: Preve di Cadere, village in Venezia, NE Italy, birthplace of TITIAN.

Cagnascis, Nicolaus Ulivis de.Entry Details: A notary public of Florence, early 17th century.

Cahors.Entry Details: City in S central France, on the Lot river; an important financial city in the Middle Ages, noted for its usurious practices.

Cai-fong-fu.Entry Details: (Kaifeng) city in HONAN province, E central China; served as the capital of the empire during the period of the Five Dynasties (907-960).

Caina attende.Entry Details: (It) Caina is waiting (Inferno, 5, 107). (Caina is a division of the lowest circle in the Inferno, containing those who have betrayed their country, family, master, or benefactor.)

Caine, Hall.Entry Details: Sir Thomas Henry Hall Caine, 1853-1931, English novelist, a friend of Dante Gabriel ROSSETTI.

C1o e Tizio.Entry Details: (It) this (man) and that man; John Doe and Richard Roe.

Cairels.Entry Details: Elias, a Provençal troubadour of the 13th century.

Calhoun, J..Entry Details: John Caldwell Calhoun, 1782-1850, member of the House of Representatives (1811-17), Secretary of War (1817-25), Vice-President (1825-32), Senator (1832-43), Secretary of State (1844-45), Senator (1845-50). From South Carolina, Calhoun was a champion of slavery and the Southern cause.

Calhoun, Mrs..Entry Details: Floride Calhoun, the wife of John CALHOUN, to whom she was married on January 8, 1811.

[ Calixtus III ].Entry Details: 1378-1458, Pope (1455-58), preceding PIUS II, quarreled with ALFONSO V of Aragon and Naples, who wanted Ancona in return for his friendship, Calixtus refused.

Calkoen.Entry Details: Hendrik, 1742-1818, Amsterdam lawyer, instrumental in swaying Dutch opinion in favor of the American colonies during the American Revolution.

Calliope.Entry Details: The muse of epic poetry. Also a steam pipe organ usually used in circus parades.

Calpe (Lyceo).Entry Details: Mount Calpe is the Rock of Gibraltar, the Calpe Club, Church Street, Gibraltar.

Calunnia, La.Entry Details: A painting by BOTTICELLI in the Uffizi Gallery, Florence.

[Calypso].Entry Details: In the Odyssey, a nymph who entertained ODYSSEUS for seven years and offered to make him immortal. He refused.

Cambaluc.Entry Details: (Khanbalik), the capital city of KUBLAI KHAN, the 'City of the Great Khan' was built (1264-67) on the site of the earlier city of Yen by Kublai Khan, site of modern Peiping.

Cambrai.Entry Details: A city in Nord department, N France. (See. LEAGUE OF CAMBRAI).

Cambreling.Entry Details: Churchill Caldom Cambreleng, 1786-1826, member of the House of Representatives (1821-39), influential leader of the House under JACKSON and VAN BUREN, appointed minister to Russia (1840-41).

Cambuskin.Entry Details: Cambyuskan or Cambiuskan, the Tartar king in Chaucer's Squire's Tale (line 12); usually identified as either GENGHIS KHAN or KUBLAI KHAN.

Camden.Entry Details: City in New Jersey; Walt WHITMAN lived his last years there.

[Campbell, John, 4th Earl of Loudoun].Entry Details: 1705-82, a commander of British forces in the French and Indian War; forced the people of Boston to quarter his troops.

Campestribus locis.Entry Details: (L) in country places (See: A. Lacharme, Confucii Chi-King, II, 3, ode 10, stanza 1).

Campiglia.Entry Details: A town in Livorno province, Italy.

Campo, Luchino del.Entry Details: Luchino dal Campo, companion of Niccolò d'ESTE on a journey to Jerusalem, and author of an account of the trip Viaggo a Gerusalemme di Niccolo da Este, descritto da Luchino dal Campo, ed by G Ghinassi, 1861.

Canal Company.Entry Details: See CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO CANAL COMPANY.

Cannabich.Entry Details: Rosa, 1764- ?, elder daughter of Christian Cannabich (1731-98), composer, and leader of the Mannheim orchestra. For Rosa, MOZART wrote the piano sonata in C (K. 309) in 1777. Of this sonata, Mozart wrote, 'Als wie Andante, so is sie 11.'

Cannes.Entry Details: Resort town on the French Riviera.

Cannon.Entry Details: James, a member of the group that framed the constitution of the state of Pennsylvania (1776).

Canossa, Rioberto da.Entry Details: Nicolecto de Canosa, an officer in the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA.

Canton.Entry Details: City and port of Kwangtung province, SE China.

Capaneus.Entry Details: One of the Seven Against THEBES; he defied Zeus to prevent him from scaling the wall, so Zeus killed him with a thunderbolt.

Cape Breton.Entry Details: Cape Breton Island, NE Nova Scotia, retained by the French after the Peace of Utrecht (1713); attached to Nova Scotia after France ceded Canada to the English (1763).

[Capellen tot den Pol, Joan Derk van der.Entry Details: Dutch statesman, friend of American interests during the late 18th century.

Capello, Bianca.Entry Details: ?1542-87, mistress of Francesco de' MEDICI, Duke of Tuscany; married to him (1579), proclaimed Grand Duchess of Tuscany four months later; said to have been poisoned by Francesco's brother, Ferdinand.

Capello, Vittor.Entry Details: Member of the Privy Council of Christoforo Moro, who became Doge in 1462.

Cape Sable.Entry Details: Cape Sable Island, off SW tip of Nova Scotia.

Capet.Entry Details: Hugh, 940-996, son of Hugh the Great; Duke of France (959-996), King of France (987-996), founder of the Capetian line of French kings.

Capoquadri.Entry Details: The name of the house in Siena where Pound used to stay during visits to the town.

Cardinal of Bologna.Entry Details: Filippo Calandrini, fl. 1450, Cardinal Bishop of Bologna.

Carlos, Don.Entry Details: The Bourbon Don Carlos, Duke of Madrid, 1848-1909, who in 1908 was living at the Palazzo Loredan, Campo San Vio, Venice.

Carmagnola.Entry Details: Francesco Bussone da, fl. 1380-1432, Italian militarist, serving under Filippo VISCONTI, Duke of Milan, later he led the forces of FLORENCE and VENICE against Visconti, his strange conduct led the Venetians to try him for treason before the Council of Ten, after which he was executed.

Carman.Entry Details: Bliss, 1861-1929, the Canadian poet and journalist.

Carmathen, Lord.Entry Details: Francis Osborne, 5th Duke of Leeds, 1751-99, known until 1789 as Marquis of Carmathen, foreign secretary under Pitt (1783-91).

Carolina.Entry Details: American colony; first charter granted by Charles I in 1629.

Carolus, King.Entry Details: See CHARLES II, Holy Roman Emperor.

Carpaccio, the.Entry Details: Reference to a painting by Vittore CARPACCIO in the Church of San Giorgio degli SCHIAVONI, Venice.

[Carpaccio, Vittore].Entry Details: C. 1450-1522, Venetian painter, pupil of Lazaro Bastiani and follower of BELLINI.

Carr, D..Entry Details: Dabney, 1773-1837, American jurist; nephew of Thomas JEFFERSON, justice of the Virginia supreme court of appeals (1824-37).

Carrara.Entry Details: The city in Tuscany, Italy; famous for its marble.

Carrière.Entry Details: Eugène, 1849-1906, French painter and lithographer, known for his Portrait of Verlaine and for decorations in the Sorbonne.

carroccio.Entry Details: (It) flag car of an army; triumphal car.

Carrol of Carrolton.Entry Details: Charles Carroll of Carrollton, 1737-1832, Revolutionary leader from Maryland, a member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1776-78), signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, a member of the U. S. Senate (1789-92).

Carrolton.Entry Details: Carrollton, Maryland, the residence of Charles CARROL(L) OF CARROL(L)TON.

Carthage.Entry Details: Ancient city of N Africa, near modern Tunis. (See HANNO).

cartouche.Entry Details: A scroll or tablet in ornamental form; also an oval monument form.

Carver.Entry Details: George Washington, ?1864-1943, American agricultural chemist who discovered many new uses for products of the South.

Cassini.Entry Details: Possibly Gherado Casini, the Roman publisher.

[Cassius Longinus, Ca1us].Entry Details: Died BC 42, a partisan of Pompey; one of the murderers of Caesar. Dante places Cassius (whom he describes as membruto, apparently in confusion with Lucius Cassius) with Brutus and Judas Iscariot in the Jaws of Lucifer in Giudecca. (See: Inferno, 34).

Castro, Ignez da.Entry Details: Inés (Inéz) de Castro, ?1320-1355, a Castilian noblewoman whom Pedro, heir to the throne of Portugal, secretly married after the death of his wife, Constance, in 1345; she was distrusted by King Alfonso IV and murdered; after Alfonso's death, Pedro had her body exhumed and placed on a throne at his side while the court paid homage to the dead queen. (See: Spirit of Romance, 231).

[Catilina, Lucius Sergius ].Entry Details: BC ?108-62, Roman politician; in BC 63 he entered into a conspiracy to assassinate the consuls and plunder Rome, but his plot was stopped by Cicero.

Cathcart, Lord.Entry Details: William Schaw, 1st Earl of Cathcart, 1755-1843, English soldier and diplomat, served in American Revolutionary War, ambassador to Russia (1813-21) when he organized the last coalition against NAPOLEON (1813).

Cats, V..Entry Details: Fl. 1783, official of the State of FRIESLAND, a member of the SOCIÉTÉ BOURGEOISE at LEEUWARD.

Catullus.Entry Details: Gaius Valerius Catullus, BC ?84-54, the Roman lyric poet.

Cavalcanti.Entry Details: Cavalcanti di Cavalcant1, d. C. 1280, father of Guido CAVALCANTI.
Guido, fl. 1250-1300, Tuscan poet, friend of DANTE. His best known poems are in the Canzone d'amore. (See: Sonnets and Ballate of Guido Cavalcanti, 1912).

caveat ire ad Turchum.Entry Details: (L) let him beware of going to the Turk. (See: MOHAMMED II).

Cavour, Count.Entry Details: Camillo Benso d1, 1810-61 Italian statesman, premier (1852-59).

Cawdor.Entry Details: Probably Cawdor Castle, Nairnshire, N Scotland.

Cayohoga.Entry Details: Cayuga Lake, W central New York, connected with Lake Seneca by a canal.

Cellesi, Sebastiano.Entry Details: Probably a member of the BALÍA of Siena, C 1622.

Celso.Entry Details: Celso Cittadini, probably a member of the BALÍA of Siena.

Celtic.Entry Details: Reference to the Celts or their language, modern Irish.

Centaur.Entry Details: A mythical creature with the body of a horse and the head of a man.

[Cephalonia].Entry Details: The largest of the Ionian Islands off Greece.

Cerinthe.Entry Details: Cerinthus, the lover of SULPICIA and the subject of her verses. (See: Tibullus III, X, 15).

Cesena.Entry Details: Town in Forli province, Emilia, Italy; controlled by the MALATESTAs from 1385-1465.

ce sont les moeurs de Lutèce.Entry Details: (Fr) these are the morals of Lutetia. (See: PARIS).

cette mauvaiseh venggg.Entry Details: (Fr) ce mauvais vent: that rotten wind (in Provençal accent?).

Ceylon.Entry Details: An island country in South Asia, now known as Sri Lanka.

[Cha-hou-keou].Entry Details: (Shaho), a town just south of MUKDEN, Manchuria.

Chaise Dieu.Entry Details: The abbey of Chaise Dieu, founded in 1046, in Brionde, near the Languedoc-Auvergne border.

Chalus.Entry Details: A château in the town of Chalus, S France, where RICHARD Coeur de Lion was killed.

[Chamber of Deputies ].Entry Details: The lower house of the French national assembly.

Champs Elysées.Entry Details: The street in Paris, known for its beauty and prominent landmarks.

chançons de gestes.Entry Details: (Fr) chansons de geste. Songs of (heroic) deeds.

Chandler, Colonel.Entry Details: A leader of the Boston pre-Revolutionary troops with which John ADAMS sometimes served.

Chang.Entry Details: (Shang), an ancient Chinese dynasty (c. BC 1766-1121) which preceded the great TCHEOU dynasty.

Chang T1.Entry Details: 53/9,10,11, 54/23, [58/65]; 60/76: (Shang T1), the Supreme Ancestor or the Ruler of Heaven; may be distinguished as the 'God Active' from the Ti'en, or 'God Passive.' Chang T1, a personalized deity, is associated with a heaven for departed spirits.

Chang-tou.Entry Details: (Shang-tu, modern Chengteh), city in Mongolia not far north of the China border; this is the city which Coleridge called Xanadu, the famous summer residence of KUBLAI KHAN and other Mongol emperors, from 1260.

Channel.Entry Details: The English Channel, the body of water that separates Southern England from Northern France.

Chantiers de la Gironde.Entry Details: The Gironde Shipyards, probably near Bordeaux.

[Chao-hao].Entry Details: (Shao Hao) (reign: 2598-2514), the fourth of the five legendary emperors of China.

Chao Kang.Entry Details: (Shao Kang) (reign: 2079-2055), this emperor came to the throne after the Interregnum of forty years when Tsuh had been deposed by the people; he quelled disorder in the Empire and gave the state of Shang its first prominence; son of Empress MIN.

Chao Kong.Entry Details: (Shao Kung) d. BC 1053; the Duke of Shao, a kinsman of WU WANG; a counselor famous for his justice dispensed from his seat under a wild pear tree.

Chaomoukong.Entry Details: (Shao Mu-kung) fl. BC 826; the name, which means Mou, Prince of Chao, was given to Chao-hou (Shao Hu) after his death. Chao-hou was a general in the service of SIUEN-OUANG. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 30; A. Lacharme, Confucii Chi-King, 308).

[Chao-tching-mao].Entry Details: (Shao Ching-mao) d. BC 497; a government official in the state of LOU; when CONFUCIUS was appointed minister of the state of Lou, he found Chao-tching-mao was causing great disorder, Confucius had him arrested and beheaded. When the followers of Chao protested, Confucius said that Chao had been a man of five vices: a man deceitful in heart, artificial in manner, vain and false in language, of vicious gossip and with a natural turn for evil.

[Chao-t'o].Entry Details: (Shao T'o) fl. BC 196, the overlord of NAN-YUEI; in 196 he proclaimed himself Prince of Yue1, but when LOU-KIA, the envoy of Emperor KAO-HOANG-TI, presented Chao-t'o with the imperial seal of office, he gave his allegiance to the emperor again.

Charent.Entry Details: The Charente river, W France, flowing into the Bay of Biscay.

Charles the Mangy.Entry Details: See CHARLES I OF NAPLES AND SICILY.

[Charles I of England].Entry Details: 1600-1649, King of England (1625-49); granted the first charter of the Colony of Massachusetts (4 March 1629).

Charles I of Naples and Sicily].Entry Details: 1226-85, King of Naples and Sicily, and count of Anjou; with consent of Pope CLEMENT IV, he attacked and defeated Manfred, King of Naples (1266) and ascended the throne of Naples. SORDELLO served in his army.

[Charles IV of Spain].Entry Details: 1748-1819, King of Spain (1788-1808), subservient to NAPOLEON, forced to abdicate (1808).

Charles le Chauve.Entry Details: See CHARLES II, Holy Roman Emperor.

Charleston.Entry Details: City in South Carolina, captured 12 May 1780 by Sir Henry Clinton and held by British forces until 14 December 1782.

[Charlotte, Sophia].Entry Details: 1744-1818, wife of GEORGE III of England.

Charter Oak.Entry Details: A white oak which stood in Hartford, Conn., until 1856. There is a story that when Sir Edmund Andros, governor general of New England, demanded (1687) that the charter of Connecticut be surrendered, the Hartford citizens hid the document in this oak.

Charybdis.Entry Details: Reference to the whirlpool, opposite SCYLLA, off the coast of Sicily, by which ODYSSEUS had to pass.

Chase.Entry Details: Samuel, 1741-1811, American patriot; signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, delegate to the First and Second CONTINENTAL CONGRESSES; appointed Associate Justice of the Supreme Court (1796).

Château Margaux.Entry Details: One of the great wines of Bordeaux.

Chatham.Entry Details: William Pitt, 1st Earl of Chatham, 1708-78, English statesman known as 'the Elder Pitt' and, later, as the 'Great Commoner'.

Chatham, the.Entry Details: An English ship captured during the American Revolution.

Chaumont, Ray de.Entry Details: Donatien le Ray de Chaumont, who in 1778 donated his house at PASSY to the American legation in Paris; Chaumont was influential and friendly toward the American Revolution and contributed supplies to the American forces.

chazims.Entry Details: Prob. variation of (Heb) hazirim. Pigs, a term of abuse.

Ché-heng.Entry Details: (Shih Hêng) d. AD 1460, one of the generals of Emperor KING-TI who defended Peiping against the Mongols in 1450. He later plotted against the Empire and died of poison.

Chéking-Tang.Entry Details: (Shih Ching-t'ang) 892-944, general and governor of Shantung province. He bribed the KHITAN Tartars with a promise of half of Chihli and Shansi to help him to the throne. In 936, he proclaimed himself emperor, ruling under the name of Kao Tsu (reign 936-44), he was the founder of the Later TSIN (Chin) dynasty.

che mai da me non S1 parte 11 diletto.Entry Details: (It) who is never departed from the pleasure of bright lightning. (See Paradiso, 23, 129, 30, 62).

Cheou-lang.Entry Details: (K'ung Shu-liang Ho) d. BC 548, father of CONFUCIUS, chief magistrate of Tsu in Shantung province. He was remarkable for his gigantic stature and great strength; after fathering nine daughters by his first wife, he remarried at seventy, and his second wife, Chêng Tsai, bore him Confucius.

Cheou-sin.Entry Details: (Chou Hsin) (reign: 1154-22), last emperor of the SHANG (or YIN) dynasty, his career was one of extravagance, lust, and cruelty, overthrown by WU WANG, he perished in the flames of his palace.

Ché-pou-kiu-atchen.Entry Details: (Shih Pu-chü Atchen) fl. 647, first officer of Che-li-sa (Shih-li-sa) of the KIEI-KOU; ambassador to the court of Emperor TAI-TSONG; demanded that the emperor give him the title of grand mandarin: since titles cost nothing, the emperor made him grand general of the army as well.

Cherokee Nation.Entry Details: Formed under the constitution (1820) by the Cherokee Indians, the largest and most important tribe in SE United States, the tribe was deported to the Indian Territory (Oklahoma) in 1838.

[Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company].Entry Details: Chartered 31 January 1825, the Company began work on the canal 4 July 1828, John Quincy ADAMS broke ground.

Chester.Entry Details: City in Cheshire county, NW England, last place in England to surrender to William the Conqueror (1070).

Chesterton.Entry Details: Gilbert Keith, 1874-1936, English journalist, writer, and defender of Catholicism, a brilliant representative of Edwardian England.

che sublia es laissa cader.Entry Details: (Pr) que s'oblid' es laissa chazer: and faint away and fall. (From a canzone of Bernart de Ventadour).

Chi.Entry Details: (Ch'1), principality in SHENSI province, ruled by WEN WANG.

Chiasso.Entry Details: Commune in Switzerland, W end of Lake Como, a custom station on the St. Gotthard railroad.

Chief Justice.Entry Details: President of the Sovereign court of GALICIA (c. 1780).

Chigi.Entry Details: Member of the famous Chigi family of Siena, member of the BALÍA (c. 1622).

Child.Entry Details: A descendant of Samuel Child, son of Sir Francis Child (1642-1713), a banker and Lord Mayor of London.

[Chinese Empire].Entry Details: (References to various areas of China that bore the name of "empire").

Chinese rites.Entry Details: The Chinese rites of worship and government.

Ching Ming.Entry Details: (Ch) (Cheng-ming)- to regulate the name; to define the correct term; precise definition. (See: Appendix B).

Chin lo-koan.Entry Details: (Shên-lo-koan), a Buddhist temple outside the city of Nanking.

Chin Nong.Entry Details: (Shen Nung) (reign: 2838-2698), second of the Five Emperors of legendary China; taught the art of agriculture; known as the "Prince of Cereals", introduced system of barter; aided by his glass-covered stomach, through which he could watch his own digestion, he studied the properties and effects of herbs.

Chinon.Entry Details: Commune, Indre-et-Loire department, NW central France.

ch'untenerisce/ a sinistra la Torre.Entry Details: (It) that softens/ the Tower at the left (See: Paradiso, 8, 2).

Chin-Tsong.Entry Details: (Shen Tsung) (reign: 1068-1086), an able administrator, ambitious for his empire, his people, and himself. His chief ally was the minister, OUANG-NGAN-CHE. They tried, however, to move too quickly and their program of sweeping reforms met stiff resistance and ended in failure.

Chin Tsong.Entry Details: (Shen Tsung) (reign: 1573-1620), his long reign ushered in the run of the MING dynasty. After the death of TCHANG-KU-TCHING, the regent, Chin-tsong abandoned himself to sensuality and extravagance. From 1585-1610 no one except the court eunuchs saw the emperor. High taxes ruined the middle class, Manchu hordes raided from the north, Japanese from the southeast, there were floods, droughts, famines, and corrupt officials.

Chisio, Augustino.Entry Details: Prob. Agostino CHIGI, 1465-1520, Sienese banker, built the Villa Farnesina in Rome; founder of the princely family of Chigi. The Latin form of the name is Chisius; the Italianized form of the Latin is here rendered Chisio.

Chi-tsong.Entry Details: (Shih Tsung) (reign: 954-959), a benevolent and generous emperor. He waged successful wars against the KHITANS and Northern HANS and enlarged the empire. When there was a scarcity of money, he ordered all copper utensils be given up for imperial uses, he also seized all the bronze images of BUDDHA and converted them into coin, remarking that Buddha, who had given up so much to mankind, was not likely to object.

[Chi-tsong].Entry Details: (Shih Tsun, also known as Oulo and as Wan-yen P'ou) fifth emperor of the KIN dynasty of the NUTCHE Tartar. During his reign (1162-90) the Kin gained much territory in China, mainly in the control of HONAN province. An exceptional man, wise and benevolent, he was sometimes called the "Little YAO and SHUN".

Chi Tsong.Entry Details: (Shih Tsung) (reign: 1522-66). Like many other MING Emperors, Chi-tsong consistently picked poor advisers and refused to listen to the most able men of his kingdom.

[Chi-tsong-hien-hoang-ti].Entry Details: (Shih Tsung Hsien Huang Ti), dynastic title of Emperor YONG-TCHING.

Chi-Tsou.Entry Details: (Shih Tsu), the name which KUBLAI KHAN took when he began his reign over China (1280).

Chittenden.Entry Details: Poss. Kate Sara Chittenden, 1856-1949, American organist, composer, and lecturer.

[Chi Tzu].Entry Details: Viscount of the principality of CHI, 12th century BC. Uncle of CHEOU-SIN, last sovereign of the YIN dynasty; because he protested against the practices of the emperor, Chi was put into prison. (See: Analects, xviii, 1).

Chiyeou.Entry Details: (Shih Yeu) fl. AD 1727, a poor laborer of SHENSI province who found a purse and gave it back to its owner without accepting a reward. Emperor YONG-TCHING was so impressed when he heard of this that he rewarded the man with a hundred ounces of silver and used the honesty of Chiyeou as the text of a long letter to his people, urging them to reform their morals. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, XI, 487-89).

Chocorua.Entry Details: Mount Chocorua, E New Hampshire, in the Sandwich Range of the White Mountains.

Cholkis.Entry Details: Prob Colchis, the kingdom of AEETES, land of the Golden Fleece.

Chou.Entry Details: (Chou), a principality in the province of SZECHWAN, S central China.

[Chouliu].Entry Details: (Shulu), d. C. AD 945, queen of the KHITAN chieftain, YE-LIU-APAOKI. She was a woman of great beauty and wisdom, and her husband often depended on her advice in matters of state and military operations.

[Christians].Entry Details: (Note that text generally uses X for the Greek letter chi: Xtians.)
