Christmas.Entry Details: Refers to the celebration of Christmas.

Christophoro, Joanne.Entry Details: Giovanni Christophoro, prob. Florentine representative at the negotiations leading to the establishment (1622) of the MONTE DEI PASCHI.

chrysalids.Entry Details: Chrysalis: the pupa stage of insects, especially of butterflies.

Chrysophrase.Entry Details: An apple-green chalcedony, used in jewelry.

Chu Hsi.Entry Details: 1130-1200, Chinese philosopher during the Southern SUNG dynasty; author of many works on the classics of CONFUCIUS.

Chun.Entry Details: (Shun) (reign: BC 2255-2205), after serving a three-year apprenticeship, Shun was selected as emperor to follow YAO; noted as a governor, astronomer, and as one who regulated the order and ceremony of religious service.

Chung.Entry Details: (Ch) center, middle, point of balance. (See: Appendix B).

Chun King.Entry Details: (Shun-ching-fu), the modern city of Chunking in SZECHWAN province.

Chun Tchi.Entry Details: (Shun Chih), first emperor of the MANCHU dynasty (reign 1644-61) to rule over China. His reign was occupied in consolidating the Manchu power by crushing the remains of the MING dynasty, in 1645 Manchu troops took Nanking, a stronghold of Ming power, and in 1662 the "last" emperor of the Ming dynasty, KUEI-WANG, was defeated. Good and generous, Chun-tchi eliminated eunuchs from the court, set up a civil administration, and treated Catholic missionaries with favor. In the last year of his reign, the Dutch were expelled from Formosa.

Chunti.Entry Details: (Shun T1) (reign 1333-68), also known as Tohan Timur, last Mongol emperor of the YUAN dynasty. Weak and pleasure-loving, he was incapable of action, and his reign was marked by continual rebellion from the Chinese. In 1368, the rebels took Peiping, the capital of the Yuan dynasty, and Chunti fled north, bringing the dynasty to an end. He died in 1370.

Churchill.Entry Details: Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill, 1874-1965, the British statesman and author.

Church of England.Entry Details: Refers to the established Christian church in England, also known as the Anglican Church.

Church St..Entry Details: A street in the Royal Borough of Kensington, London, in a court off which Pound lived (1909-1914).

Ciano.Entry Details: Conte Galeazzo Ciano di Cortelazzo, 1903-1944, Italian statesman, secretary of state for press and propaganda (1935), minister of foreign affairs (1936-43), ambassador to the Holy See (1943). He was the son-in-law of MUSSOLINI.

Cicero.Entry Details: Marcus Tullius Cicero, also known as TULLY, 106-43 BC, Roman orator, and philosopher.

Cigale, a.Entry Details: The dance hall and restaurant near the Place Pigalle, Montmarte, Paris.

Cigna.Entry Details: Locality in central Italy taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

cimier.Entry Details: An ornament forming the apex or crest on a helmet.

Ciola.Entry Details: Locality in central Italy taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

Circe.Entry Details: The enchantress who turned men into swine. ODYSSEUS avoids her spell with the aid of the herb, MOLY, and becomes her lover. She informs him that to return to ITHACA, he must first seek out TIRESIAS in Hades.

Circeo.Entry Details: Monte Circeo, the N side of the Gulf of Gaeta, W Italy; once the island called Aeaea, home of CIRCE.

Circe Titania.Entry Details: Titanian CIRCE (as Circe is the daughter of the Sun). (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses XIV, 382, 438).

Clara Leonora.Entry Details: Prob. a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania, 1906.

Clarendon, Earl.Entry Details: A pseudonym used by John ADAMS in a series of letters sent to the BOSTON GAZETTE in 1765.

Claridge's.Entry Details: The fashionable hotel on Brook Street, London.

Clarke, Gen..Entry Details: Henri Jacques Guillaume Clarke, 1765-1818, Duke of Feltre, Napoleonic general.

Classe.Entry Details: A town in Ravenna, Italy. Sigismondo took marble for the TEMPIO from the church of SANT APOLLINAIRE in Classe, though against the wishes of the people of Ravenna.

Clay.Entry Details: Henry Clay, 1777-1852, American lawyer, and statesman, member of the House of Representatives (1811-14, 1815-21; 1823-25); supported John Quincy ADAMS in the Presidential election of 1824, served as Secretary of State (1825-29); U. S. Senator (1849-52).

Clement.Entry Details: Saint Clement I, Pope ?88-97?; also known as Clement of Rome.

[Clement XI].Entry Details: 1649-1721, Pope (1700-21), he condemned the custom of Chinese ancestor worship and denied the Jesuit petition that the Mass might be said in the Chinese language.

Clinton, DeWitt.Entry Details: 1769-1828, New York lawyer, and statesman, U. S. Senator (1802-03), mayor of New York, an unsuccessful candidate for the Presidency (1812); governor of New York (1817-21; 1825-28).

Clinton, George.Entry Details: 1739-1812, New York lawyer, and statesman; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1775-76), brigadier general (1777); governor of New York (1777-95, 1801-04); Vice President (1805-12).

Clinton.Entry Details: Sir Henry, ?1738-95, English soldier; succeeded Howe as commander-in-chief of British forces in North America (1778).
Small town in N central New York, near Utica; the site of Hamilton College, at which Pound was in residence 1903-1905.

Clowes.Entry Details: A member of the English printing firm of William Clowes and Sons, Ltd., London.

Cnidos.Entry Details: Cnidus, the ancient town at Cape Kr10, SW Asia Minor, once a Dorian city noted for its wealth, sculpture, and architecture. Praxiteles' statue of APHRODITE was at Cnidus.

Cochran, Tommy.Entry Details: Not enough information available to identify the individual.

Cockle.Entry Details: James, fl. 1761, an officer of the customs in Salem, Massachusetts, who petitioned the court to grant him WRITS OF ASSISTANCE to let him search for prohibited merchandise. James OTIS and Oxenbridge THACHER represented the protesting Boston merchants; Jeremiah GRIDLEY appeared for Cockle in support of the writs. Cockle won his case, known as the Paxton case.

Cocteau.Entry Details: Jean, 1891-, French poet, playwright, and man of letters.

[Cocytus].Entry Details: The river of Hell, in the Inferno, it is a marsh formed by the tears of this world.

Coke, Lord.Entry Details: Sir Edward Coke, 1552-1634, English jurist, best known for his four Institutes (1628-44), the first of which is called Coke upon Littleton.

Col credito suo / Napoli a Venezia di da.Entry Details: (It) With that debt / Naples and Venice of money / Forced / Naples and Venice / to that peace.

Cole, G. D. H..Entry Details: George Douglas Howard, 1880-, English economist and novelist.

Cole, Horace.Entry Details: Possibly the Horace Cole, 1874-, who was the secretary of Geo. Newnes Ltd. and other companies, and a contributor to 20th Century Business Practice, The Hub, etc.

[Colloredo, Graf Hieronhymus Joseph].Entry Details: 1732-1812, Archbishop of Salzburg in 1772; was a patron of MOZART for a time.

Cologne.Entry Details: German manufacturing city. The Cologne Cathedral, a Gothic structure, was begun C. 1248, completed 1880.

Comley.Entry Details: Possibly associated with Cheltenham Military Academy, Ogontz, Pa., at which Pound was a student, c. 1900.

Commendatore.Entry Details: (It) A knight of a chivalric order.

Comment! Vous êtes tombés S1 bas?.Entry Details: (Fr) What! You have fallen so low?

Commission to France.Entry Details: The commission sent by the Colonies to France in 1776; members: Benjamin FRANKLIN, Arthur LEE, and Silas DEANE. Later in the year, John ADAMS replaced Deane.

commune sepulchrum/ Aurum est commune se.Entry Details: (L) The common sepulchre/ Gold is the common sepulchre. Usury, the common sepulchre.

Como.Entry Details: Lake Como in Lombardy, N Italy.

Compleynt, compleynt I hearde upon a day.Entry Details: Possibly a variation of Chaucer, The Complaint Unto Pity.

Concord.Entry Details: The town in NE Massachusetts, famous for its literary associations.

Condorcet.Entry Details: Marie Jean Antoine Nicholas de Caritat, Marquis de, 1743-94, French philosopher, mathematician, and politician.

Coney Island.Entry Details: The amusement park in Brooklyn, N. Y.

Confucius.Entry Details: K'ung Ch'iu or K'ung Fu Tzu or K'ung) 551-479, Chinese philosopher and statesman. Confucianism is an organized series of precepts dealing with morals, the family system, social reforms, statecraft, and ceremonials; considers action, directed by right thinking, to be the highest good, postulates the innate virtue of man. It opposes the passivity of Buddhism and the mysticism of Taoism. A philosophy of reason, it influenced the thought of the French Enlightenment.

Cong-ho.Entry Details: (kung-ho), the historical name for the interregnum (BC 841-27) between the reign of LI-WANG and SIUEN-OUANG, his son.

con gli occhi onesti e tardi.Entry Details: (It) With eyes honest and slow. (See: Purgatorio, 6, 63, where text reads: E nel muover degli occhi onesta e tarda).

Congress.Entry Details: See CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES.

[Congressional Globe 1:37/35.Entry Details: Containing the Debates and Proceedings, 1833-73, a newspaper published in Washington, D. C., 109 vol.

[Congress of the United States 22/101(?).Entry Details: The legislative branch of the Federal government; instituted (1789) by the CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.

Connecticut constitution.Entry Details: The Connecticut Charter, granted (1662) to John Winthrop.

connubium terrae. mysterium.Entry Details: (L) The marriage of the earth mystery.

Constans proposito / Justum et Tenocem.Entry Details: (L) Constant in purpose.../ just and enduring. (See: Horace, Odes, III, 3; J. Q. Adams, Diary, 568; see also ET AMAVA PERDUTA-MENTE.

Constitution.Entry Details: See CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.

Constitution of the United States].Entry Details: The document which established the system of Federal government in the United States; drawn up at the FEDERAL CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION at Philadelphia (1787) and ratified by the required number of states (nine) by 21 June 1788.

Consules, Iudices pro serenissimo.Entry Details: (L) Consuls, judges for his most serene.

consuls.Entry Details: The joint magistrates of the Roman Republic.

[Contarin]].Entry Details: Ancient Venetian family which produced eight doges, a cardinal, and several artists; most celebrated member of the family was Andrea Contarini (?1300-82), Doge at the time of the War of Chioggia between Venice and Genoa. Text reference is to the Palazzo Contarini, Calle della Vida, Venice.

Continental Army].Entry Details: American army during the Revolution; created in 1775 by the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS, it was commanded by George WASHINGTON.

Continental Congress ].Entry Details: 1774-89; the Federal legislature of the Thirteen Colonies and, later, of the United States.

contra barbaros/ legat belli ducem.Entry Details: (L) Against the barbarians/ he appoints a leader in war. (See: A. Lacharme, Confucii Chi-King, 308).

Contrarin, Ugaccion dei.Entry Details: A member of the CONTARINI family of Venice.

Contre le lambris, fauteuil de paille, /.Entry Details: (Fr) Against the panelling, straw arm-chair, / An old piano, and under the barometer. (See: Flaubert, Un Coeur Simple).

Conversations upon Political Economy.Entry Details: Illustrations of Political Economy (1832-34), by Harriet MARTINEAU.

coram non judice.Entry Details: (L) Not in the presence of a judge.

Corcoran, Captain.Entry Details: A pseudonym having no particular reference.

Córdoba.Entry Details: Capital of Córdoba province in S Spain.

Corey.Entry Details: William Ellis, 1866-1934, American industrialist, president of Carnegie Steel Co. (1901-03) and U. S. Steel Corp. (1903-11).

Corinth.Entry Details: City in S Greece; one of the cities represented at the Council of Ferrara-Florence (1438).

Cornelison.Entry Details: Sergeant in the Provost section, DTC, Pisa.

Cornwallis.Entry Details: Charles, 1738-1805, British general defeated by the Americans and French at Yorktown, 1781.

Corpus.Entry Details: Corpus Christi: a feast of the Catholic Church, honoring the institution of the Eucharist, the Thursday after Trinity Sunday.

Corre, volpe corre, Christu corre, volpe.Entry Details: (It) Runs, the fox runs, Christ runs, fox runs, / Christ runs, and made a jump, and took the tail/ Of the fox.

[Correggio, Ghiberto da].Entry Details: One of the officers of Sigismondo MALATESTA when he was employed by the Sienese.

Correze.Entry Details: Department and river in S central France.

Cortona.Entry Details: Town in Tuscany, central Italy; its churches have paintings by Fra ANGELICO and Luca Signorelli.

Corunna.Entry Details: Seaport commune of Coruna province in NW Spain.

Cosa deve continuare? Se casco / non cas.Entry Details: (It) Why must it go on? If I fall / I will not fall on my knees.

cosi discesi per l'aer maligno/ on doit.Entry Details: (It) So it is said through the spiteful air / (Fr) One must take the weather as it comes. (See: Inferno, 5, 1 and 86).

Cossa.Entry Details: Francesco del, fl. 1435-1477? Italian painter; his Glorification of March, April, and May frescoes are in the SCHIFANOJA Palace, Ferrara.

cossacks.Entry Details: Russian peasant cavalrymen serving the czars.

Cotta.Entry Details: Johannes, 1480-1510, Italian poet, and humanist, a friend of Girolamo FRACASTORO, helped Bartolomeo d'ALVIANO found an academy of arts.

counties palatine.Entry Details: Counties in England in which the earl ruled under exclusive royal powers; in law, such powers are now mostly abolished.

[Coupatal].Entry Details: (Cupat'a1) d. 1735 AD, a general and president of the Tribunal of Rites, he had been picked by KANG-HI to be tutor to YONG-TCHING.

[Couplet, Philippe].Entry Details: Fl. 1680, Jesuit missionary in China; he arrived in Peiping with VERBIEST (1660) and served as procurator of the China missions. In 1680 he returned to Rome, carrying Verbiest's plea for ordination of Chinese priests and a vernacular Mass.

Court House.Entry Details: The Court House in Boston, Mass.

Coxie.Entry Details: Jacob Sechler Coxey, 1854-1951, American reformer, and politician.

Creeks.Entry Details: American Indian confederacy, located in the southeast U. S.

[Cremona].Entry Details: Fortified commune in Lombardy, N Italy, on the Po river.

[Cretensis, Georgius Dartona].Entry Details: Made a Latin translation of the Homeric Hymns. (See: Make It New, 145-146).

Creusot.Entry Details: Le Creusot, city in Saone-et-Loire department, E central France; location of the SCHNEIDER iron and steel mills and munitions plants.

Crevel.Entry Details: René, 1900-, French author; Les Pieds dans le plat (1933).

Crimea.Entry Details: Peninsula in S Soviet Russia, extending into the Black Sea, scene of the Crimean War (1854-56).

croce di Malta, figura del sol.Entry Details: (It) Cross of MALTA, image of the sun.

Cul de Sac.Entry Details: The cul-de-sac Tete-bout, Paris, in the hotel at which Jefferson stayed (October 1784).

Cumae.Entry Details: Site of the grotto of the Cumaean Sibyl, on a promontory in Campania, the earliest Greek colony in Italy, founded in the 8th century BC.

cum delegans revocarit.Entry Details: (L) When one who sends a delegate calls him back. (See: Bracton, De Legibus, III, 10, where text reads: Item cum delegans revocaverit jurisdictionem; John Adams, Works, III, 546).

Cummings.Entry Details: Edward Estlin Cummings, 1894-, the American poet.
Homer Stille Cummings, 1870-1956, the American lawyer and politician, U. S. Attorney General (1933-39).

Curie.Entry Details: Pierre Curie, 1859-1906, French chemist, and physicist.

Cushing.Entry Details: Thomas Cushing, 1725-88, American political leader, member of the Boston Committee of Correspondence (1773), and of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-76).

custos rotolorum.Entry Details: (L) Custos rotulorum. Keeper of the rolls (of peace). (See: John Adams, Works, III, 527).

Cypri munimenta sortita est.Entry Details: (L) The citadels of CYPRUS are her appointed realm. (See: Georgius Dartona Cretensis, Homeric Hymn VI, To Aphrodite, 2).

Cyprus.Entry Details: Island in the E Mediterranean; a center of the worship of APHRODITE.

Cyrne.Entry Details: Island of Cerne, or Herne, in the mouth of the R10 de Oro on the west coast of Africa; HANNO stopped there on his periplus.

Cyrenians.Entry Details: People of the ancient city of Cyrene in the part of Africa known as Cyrenaica, the modern Barca.

Cythera.Entry Details: Epithet of APHRODITE, from the association of the goddess with the island of Cythera, off the SE coast of Laconia.

Dai.Entry Details: (Jap) Great. The term is used to refer to the Dairi dynasty of Japan and by extension to the Japanese emperors.

Dai Nippon Banzai.Entry Details: (Jap) Long live the Japanese Empire, Hail to the greatness of Japan.

Dalmatia.Entry Details: Territory on the E shore of the Adriatic Sea.

Danae.Entry Details: Daughter of Acrisius, king of Argos; having been told by an oracle that he would be killed by his daughter's son, Acrisius had Danae imprisoned in a bronze tower. But Zeus took pity on her and visited her in a shower of gold, as a result of this visit, Danae bore a son, Perseus. Acrisius set Danae and Perseus adrift in a sea chest. After many adventures, Perseus returned and accidentally killed Acrisius with a discus, thus fulfilling the oracle.

danar.Entry Details: An early Italian coin (from (It) danaro: money).

Danegeld.Entry Details: (OE) An annual tax paid by the Britons to the Danes; continued in later history as a land tax.

da parte/ de non. / non sincere.Entry Details: Prob. (It) on the side (i.e., affirmative) / of no (i.e., negatively) / unverified (or not genuine).

[Daphne].Entry Details: Daphne, pursued by APOLLO, was at her entreaty changed into a bay tree (the Greek laurel), which thus became sacred to Apollo.

D' 'Arcy.Entry Details: William Knox, Australian oilman, founded the Anglo-Persian Oil Company after first obtaining (1901) the oil concession from the Shah of Persia.

Das Bankgeschaft.Entry Details: (Ger) The banking business. (See: Georg Obst, Das Bankgeschäft, 1914).

Das Kapital.Entry Details: The economic study by Karl MARX.

daughter of Ocean.Entry Details: Any sea nymph sired by OCEAN.

David rex.Entry Details: (L) King David, d. C. BC 972, king of the Hebrews.

Davila.Entry Details: Enrico Caterino, 1576-1631, Italian soldier, and historian, author of History of French Civil Wars (1630), on Davila's work John ADAMS based his Discourses on Davila (1790), a series of papers written to demonstrate that a government must be strong if it is to survive faction.

Davis, Jeff.Entry Details: Jefferson Davis, 1808-89, President of the Confederate States of America (1861-65).

Dawn in Britain, The.Entry Details: An epic poem by Charles Montague DOUGHTY (1906).

Dawson.Entry Details: John, 1762-1814, member of the House of Representatives (1797-1814), the bearer to Paris of the ratified Convention with France (1800).

Deane.Entry Details: Silas, 1737-89, American diplomat, commercial representative in France (1776). Charged with profiteering (1778), he was not able to clear himself and spent the rest of his life in exile. In 1842 Congress granted restitution to his heirs.

Decennio.Entry Details: The tenth-anniversary celebration of Italian Fascism (1932).

der Miracoli.Entry Details: The Santa Maria dei Miracoli, a church in Rome.

Del Carmine.Entry Details: Giuliano del Carmine, an astrologer who predicted the murder of Alessandro de' MEDICI.

[Delia].Entry Details: A reference to ARTEMIS, the goddess of Delos.

De libro Chi-King SIC censo Ut animum no.Entry Details: (L) Ita domino...: Concerning the book SHIH CHING I think thus To purge our minds, CONFUCIUS says, / and guide (them) to the light of reason with perpetual effect The Shih Ching shows and exhorts. But the just man/ and the one free of lust so serves his master obeys his parents/ never turns aside therefore in my eulogies, CHUN TCHI (It) eleventh year. (See: A. Lacharme, Confucu Chi-King, X1-X11, Guide to Kulchur, 249).

de litteris et de armis, praestantibusqu.Entry Details: (L) About letters and arms, and men of outstanding genius. (From Platina. Petunt quid mihi colloquil fuerit cum Sigismundo Malatesta, qui tum in Urbe erat. De litteris, inquam, de armis, de praestanti- bus ingeniis tum veterum, tum nostrorum hominum loquebamur, deque his rebus, quae in hominum colloquia cadere possunt. (See. Muratori, Rerum Italicarum Scriptores, III, part I (1923), 384, also quoted in Yriarte, Un Condottiere au XVe Siècle, 319).

de lonh.Entry Details: (Pr) Far-off. (From a song of Jaufre Rudel; see Spirit of Romance, 42).

Delort.Entry Details: Jean-Francois Delort de Gleon, 1769-1812, officer in the Napoleonic Army of Italy, serving under General Pierre Antoine Dupont de l'ETANG.

Delphos.Entry Details: Ancient shrine of APOLLO, on Mt. Parnassus.

Demeter.Entry Details: The goddess of corn, of the harvest, of fruitfulness; the mother of PERSEPHONE.

de mis soledades vengan.Entry Details: (Sp) Out of my solitude let them come. (From a poem of Lope de Vega: de mis soledades vengo.. see Spirit of Romance, 208).

de mortuis.Entry Details: (L) About the dead; (de mortuis nil nisi bonum).

Dempsey, Jack.Entry Details: William Harrison Dempsey, 1895-, the American heavyweight boxing champion (1919-1926).

Deo similis quodam modo hic intellectus.Entry Details: (L) Godlike in a way this intellect that has grasped. (From Albertus Magnus; see Literary Essays, 186).

depuis qu'1l est enfermé à la Tour.Entry Details: (Fr) Since he has been locked up in the TOWER. (See: John Adams, Works, VII, 323).

Deputies of Holland and Zeeland.Entry Details: Baron de Lynden de BLITTERSWYK and Baron Van den Santheuvel.

Der im Baluba das Gewitter gemacht hat.Entry Details: (Ger) (He) who made the tempest in BALUBA.

Desdemona.Entry Details: Wife of Othello in Othello. The so-called Ca' Desdemona is the Contarini-Fasan palace, Grand Canal, Venice.

[Deseilligny, Alfred Pierrot].Entry Details: 1828-75, son-in-law of Joseph-Eugène SCHNEIDER, and co-manager of the ironworks with Henri Schneider, son of Joseph-Eugène.

Despenser, Hugh le.Entry Details: Earl of Winchester, 1262-1326, supported Edward III and was beheaded as a traitor.
d. 1326, son of Hugh le Despenser the elder, was beheaded as a traitor.

des Petits Augustins.Entry Details: The rue des Petits Augustins, Paris; the Hôtel d'Orleans was on this street. John JAY stopped there.

Destutt de Tracy, Comte Antoine Louis Cl.Entry Details: 1754-1836, French philosopher and member of the States-General (1789).

Des valeurs, / Nom de Dieu, et/ encore d.Entry Details: (Fr) Stocks and bonds, / for God's sake, and/ more stocks and bonds.

Detroit Michilimakinac.Entry Details: A military fort controlled by the British on the Strait of Mackinac, near Detroit, Michigan, finally relinquished to the Americans.

deus nec laedit amantes.Entry Details: (L) Nor does God harm lovers. (See Tibullus, III, X, 15).

Deux Avares, Le.Entry Details: A play by Fenouillot de Falbaire de Quing ey (1770).

Diaz, Ruy.Entry Details: Rodrigo Diaz de Bivar (or Vivar), ?1040-1099, Cid, Spanish soldier of fortune who served under Sancho IV Navarre and Alfonso VI, banished by Alfonso, he served the Arab kings of Sargossa, capturing and ruling Valencia and Murcia until he was overthrown and killed, hero of the Spanish epic Poeman del Cid.

Dickenson.Entry Details: John Dickinson, 1732-1808, American statesman, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774, 1775, 1779) and delegate from Delaware to the Federal Constitutional Convention. In the Continental Congress, Dickinson was a leader of those who desired conciliation with England at almost any cost. (See: John Adams, Works, II, 414-29).

D1 cui godeva molto.Entry Details: (It) In which very much enjoyed himself.

Dido.Entry Details: The legendary queen of Carthage who loved Aeneas.

Dieci della Balia.Entry Details: The Council of Ten of the Balía; the ruling authority of Florence.

Dilectis miles familiaris castra Montis.Entry Details: (L) My beloved and familiar soldier the castles of MONTE ODORISO (and) MONTE SAN SILVESTRO to have and to hold (?) / in the district of Thetis. (See. Cesare de Lollis, Vita e Poesie di Sordello di Goito, 61).

Diocletian.Entry Details: Gaius Aurelius Valerius Diocletianus, 245-313, Roman Emperor (284-306).

Diodorus Siculus.Entry Details: Sicilian historian of the first century BC; author of Biblioteca Historica (40 vol.)

Dione.Entry Details: An obscure Greek deity, thought to be either a local form of Earth Mother or a sky goddess; consort of Zeus, mother of APHRODITE.

Dionysius of Syracuse.Entry Details: Dionysius the Elder, 430-367, tyrant of Syracuse (405-367), PLATO lived at his court for a time during 388 as tutor to Dionysius the Younger.

Dionysus.Entry Details: The god of wine, fertility and ecstasy.

Dirce.Entry Details: In Greek mythology, the wife of Lycus, king of the city later called Thebes, she was put to death by Amphion and Zethus, who tied her on the horns of a bull.

directio voluntatis.Entry Details: (L) Direction of the will. (See: Dante, De Vulgari Eloquentia, II, 2).

Directory, the.Entry Details: A five-man executive committee during the French Revolution; abolished by Napoleon after the coup of 18 BRUMAIRE.

Dis.Entry Details: The god of the underworld, the Greek Pluto, consort of PERSEPHONE.

Discobolus.Entry Details: Statue of the discus thrower by the Greek sculptor, Myron; only copies exist, the best known of which is the Lancelotti Discobolus.

Disraeli.Entry Details: Benjamin, 1st Earl of Beaconsfield, 1804-1881, the British statesman and author, prime minister (1874-80).

Divus, Andreas.Entry Details: Author of a Latin translation of the Odyssey, printed in Paris, 1538. (See: Make It New, 137-146).

Dogana's steps.Entry Details: The Dogana di Mare, custom-house in Venice.

doivent tousjours crier la Liberté, -- a.Entry Details: (Fr) (They) ought always to cry Liberty -- friends of France. (See: John Adams, Works, I, 345 note).

Dolmetsch.Entry Details: Arnold, 1853-1940, French musician and instrument maker, especially of early stringed and keyed instruments, the Dolmetsch Foundation (1928) was founded to encourage interest in old music.

Dolores.Entry Details: Possibly referring to 'dolores' meaning 'pains' or 'sorrows' in Spanish/Italian.

Domat.Entry Details: Jean, 1625-95, French jurist, author of The Civil Laws in their Natural Order (1689-94).

Dome Book.Entry Details: The Domesday Book, started about 1066 by William the Conqueror, a record of lands owned in England, their values, and their owners.

Domenica.Entry Details: Island and British colony in the British West Indies.

Dominant, The.Entry Details: Traditional term applied to Venice - Venezia Dominante.

domna jauzionda.Entry Details: (Pr) The gay mother, the pleasure-seeking, pleasure-giving mother. (See Bernart de Ventadour, Tant a1 mo cor ple de joya, 53).

Donatello.Entry Details: Donato di Niccolò di Betto Bardi, ?1386-1466, Italian sculptor of the early Renaissance, or possibly the character in Hawthorne's Marble Faun.

Don Ferdinandus Secundus Dux Magnus.Entry Details: (L) Lord Ferdinand the Second, Mighty Leader. (See: FERDINAND II of Tuscany).

don't work so hard.Entry Details: Variation of Mencius, II, I, 11, 16. 'Let not the mind forget its work, but let there be no assisting the growth of that nature.'

Dortmund.Entry Details: A German beer, Dortmunder Aktien Brauere1.

Doughty.Entry Details: Charles Montagu, 1843-1926, English traveler and writer, author of Arabia Deserta (1888) and an epic poem, The Dawn in Britain (1906).

Douglas.Entry Details: Clifford Hugh, 1879-1952, British engineer and social economist, founder of Social Credit.

dove fu Elena rapta da Paris.Entry Details: (It) Where HELEN was kidnapped by PARIS.

Dover.Entry Details: Borough of Kent in SE England, on the Strait of Dover.

dove sta memoria..Entry Details: (It) Where one remembers. (See: Cavalcant1, Donna m1 prega in Translations, 134).

Dowland.Entry Details: John, 1563-1626, the English composer and lutenist.

Drake, the.Entry Details: An English ship captured by John Paul JONES in 1779.

dreitz hom.Entry Details: (Pr) A right good man, a man of upright character.

Dryad.Entry Details: A tree nymph which lived only as long as the particular tree it was associated with.

D.T.C..Entry Details: Disciplinary Training Center, near Pisa, Italy, U.S. Army prison camp, 1945.

Duane.Entry Details: William, 1760-1835, American journalist interested in South America.

du Barry.Entry Details: Jeanne Bécu, comtesse du Barry, 1743-03, mistress of Louis XV of France.

Dublin pilot.Entry Details: Possibly refers to a pilot guide or book for Dublin.

ducatorum? no. ducentorum.Entry Details: (L) Of ducats? No. of two hundred.

Duccio.Entry Details: Duccio di Buoninsegna, 1278-1319, Italian painter and leading representative of the Sienese school.

Duccio, Ottaviano d'Antonio d1.Entry Details: 1418- ?, Florentine sculptor; went to Rimini in 1446 to work on the TEMPIO; major designer of the Tempio decorations.

Dudley.Entry Details: Edmund, a justice during the reign of Henry VII of England.

Dulac.Entry Details: Edmund, 1882- the French artist and illustrator.

Dumas.Entry Details: Charles William Fredrick, d. 1794, Swiss man of letters whom Franklin employed as an agent to promote American affairs in Holland (1775); he acted as secretary for John DWARFS Adams in Holland (1780-82) and remained there as American chargé d'affaires.
Alexandre--Dumas fils-- 1824-95, the French playwright and novelist.

dum capitolium scandet..Entry Details: (L) As long as he goes up the Capitol Hill. (See Horace, Odes 3, 30).

Dum spiro/ Dum spiro amo.Entry Details: (L) While I breathe, while I breathe I love. (See: John Adams, Works, IX, 569).

Dupont.Entry Details: See Pierre Antoine Dupont de l'ETANG.

Dutch.Entry Details: Refers to the people or things related to the Netherlands.

Dutch constitution.Entry Details: The agreements which bound the states of the Netherlands together under the STADTHOLDER, the Netherlands' Constitution was promulgated in 1814 and established a constitutional monarchy.

dwarfs, the.Entry Details: Reference to El Primo, a portrait by VELASQUEZ in the PRADO.

\"each one in the name of its god\" (eac.Entry Details: From Micah, 4, 5: 'For all people will walk everyone in the name of his god.'

E al Triedro, Cunizza/ e l'altra \"Io so.Entry Details: (It) And in the corner, CUNIZZA/ and the other (woman). 'I am the Moon.'

East End of London.Entry Details: That part of London lying east of the Bank of England.

Eaton.Entry Details: John Henry, 1790-1856, American lawyer and politician, member of the U. S. Senate (1818-29), Secretary of War (1829-31), minister to Spain (1836-40). His second wife was Peggy EATON, whom he married in 1829.
Joseph. fl. 1766, a Massachusetts lawyer of doubtful character.

Eaton, Peggy.Entry Details: Margaret Eaton, known as Peggy, 1796-1879, the daughter of a Washington, D. C. innkeeper; she married John B. Timberlake (d. 1828) and then John Henry EATON in 1829. When Eaton became U. S. Secretary of War (1829) the wives of the other cabinet members refused to accept Mrs. Eaton socially. Although President JACKSON tried to quiet the matter, Eaton was forced to resign in 1831.

Eblis.Entry Details: Eblis II, Viconte of VENTADOUR, a 12th-century Provençal nobleman.

Ecbatan.Entry Details: Ecbatana, ancient capital of Media Magna, founded in the 6th century BC by the legendary first king of the Medes, Deioces. According to Herodotus, the city was surrounded by seven concentric walls, each a different color, and the citadel was a treasure house.

e che fu chiamata Primavera.Entry Details: (It) and who was called Spring. (See: Dante, La Vita Nuova, XXIV, 20-23).

Echelles.Entry Details: Echelles du Levant, the commercial ports of the Near East on the Mediterranean, they were long under Turkish control.

Ecole Militaire.Entry Details: Building at the southern end of the Champ-de-Mars, Paris; built by Louis XV and used since as the French General Staff College.

Ed ascoltando al leggier mormorio.Entry Details: (It) And listening to the light murmur.

Edgar.Entry Details: Edgar the Peaceful, 944-75, King of the English (959-75).

Edgardus Anglorum Basileus/ insularum oc.Entry Details: (L) EDGAR, King of the English, / emperor and ruler of the isles of the ocean, I thank/ almighty God who so enlarged and extended my kingdom beyond the kingdom of my fathers, / granted the good offices of divinity / Ireland has a parliament. (See: Coke, Reports, 7, 22b, John Adams, Works, IV, 161).

E difficile, A Firenze difficile viver r.Entry Details: (It) It is difficult/ in Florence to live in wealth/ without having possessions. / "And PICCININO, having none, / "had to be feared by anyone who had them.

e di questu/ Fu fatta, e per questu/ E l.Entry Details: (It) and of this/ Was made, / and for this/ And the woman is a fury, A fury and a rage.

Edmée.Entry Details: A name mentioned in the book.

Edward the Confessor.Entry Details: ?1002-66, last of the Anglo-Saxon monarchs of England, ruled 1043-66.

Edwards.Entry Details: Ninian, 1775-1833, U. S. Senator from Illinois (1818-24).

Edwardus Deo Gratia Angliae/ Dom. Hib. e.Entry Details: (L) Edward by the Grace of God (King) of England,/Lord of Ireland, and Duke of Aquitaine (holding) the land of Wales together with its inhabitants /in possession of our private ownership. (See: John Adams, Works, IV, 134).

e \"fa di clarita l'aere tremare\".Entry Details: (It) and makes the air tremble with light. (See: Cavalcant1, Sonnet VII).

Egeria.Entry Details: The nymph who, in Roman legend, gave advice to King Numa in the Arician wood. Also a classical idealization of a mistress. (See Livy, I, xix, 5).

ego, scriptor cantilenae.Entry Details: (L) I, the writer of the canto.

E gradment li antichi cavaler romanj/ da.Entry Details: (It) and greatly the ancient Roman Knights believed these signs. (See: Tonini, Rimini nella Signoria de' Malatesta, 283, for this transcription from Broglio)

Egypt.Entry Details: A country located in northeastern Africa and bordered by the Mediterranean Sea to the north. The ancient civilization of Egypt played a significant role in human history.

[Eighteenth Amendment].Entry Details: The Eighteenth Amendment to the CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES, prohibiting the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors, ratified 16 January 1919 by Nebraska, the 36th state to do so, repealed 1933.

eijen.Entry Details: (Ch) barbarian (?); possibly a misspelling of ELJEN (Magyar) Hail!

Eileen.Entry Details: A name mentioned in the book.

eiusdem civitatis Senen.Entry Details: (L) of the same city of Siena.

Elba.Entry Details: Italian island in the Mediterranean on which Napoleon was confined in 1814.

Eleanor.Entry Details: Eleanor of AQUITAINE, 1122-1204, daughter of William X of Aquitaine, married LOUIS VII of France (1137) and Henry of ANJOU (afterward HENRY II of England) in 1152, mother of Henry, Richard I and John of England.

Eleusis.Entry Details: Town in Attica where the Eleusinian Mysteries of Demeter were held. Originally an agrarian festival, the Eleusinian Mysteries came to be concerned with the underworld deities, descent into Hades, and mystic visions of future life.

Eleutes.Entry Details: Or Eleuths, a nomadic tribe to the north and northwest of China, the period of their greatest power was 1680-96, when they were led by KALDAN.

Elias, Mr..Entry Details: A name mentioned in the book.

Elinus, Don.Entry Details: A son of FARINATO DE FARINATI.

Eliot.Entry Details: Thomas Stearns, 1888-, the poet, and critic; also referred to as POSSUM.

Elizondo, Padre José.Entry Details: José Maria de, Spanish priest who helped Pound get a photostat of the Cavalcanti manuscript in the Escorial, Madrid. (See: Guide to Kulchur, 158).

Ellébeuse, Clara d'.Entry Details: A character in the novel Clara d'Ellébeuse ou l'histoire d'une ancienne jeune fille (1899) by Francis Jammes; also the name is to be found in Jammes' De l'angélus de l'aube à l'angélus du soir (1898).

[Elliot, Sir Henry George].Entry Details: 1817-1907, English diplomat who was sent on special missions to Naples (1859) and to Greece (1862); ambassador at Vienna (1877-84); son of the second earl of Minto.

Ellsworth.Entry Details: Oliver, 1745-1807, American statesman and jurist, delegate to the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1777-84), Chief Justice of the U. S. (1796-99); sent to France to negotiate with NAPOLEON (1800).

E'l Marchese.Entry Details: (It) And the Marquis was about to turn crazy. (See: Niccolò d'ESTE).

e l'olors/d'eno1 ganres.Entry Details: (Pr) and the smell of weariness (wretchedness) you will win (gain) (See Arnaut Daniel, Er vei vermeils. in Literary Essays, 139).

e lo soleils plovil.Entry Details: (Pr) the sun with the rain in it. (See: Arnaut Daniel, IV: Lancan son passat li giure).

E lo Sordels si fo di Mantovana.Entry Details: (Pr) and the SORDELLOs are from Mantua. (From a manuscript in the Ambrosian Library, Milan; see Literary Essays, 97).

Elpenor.Entry Details: a companion of ODYSSEUS who fell off the roof of CIRCE's dwelling, was killed and left unburned. His is the first shade met by Odysseus in Hades, he asks that he be buried and that his oar be planted on his grave. (See: Odyssey, X-XII).

Elskamp.Entry Details: Max, 1862-1931, Belgian symbolist poet associated with the Catholic renaissance in Belgium.

Elson.Entry Details: a missionary known by Pound in Gibraltar, 1906? 1908?

el triste pensier S1 volge/ad Ussel. A V.Entry Details: (It) the sad thought goes/to USSEL. To VENTADOUR/goes his counsel, time returns.

Elvira.Entry Details: sister of King SANCHO in de Vega's Las Almenas de Toro.

Elysée.Entry Details: the Palais de l'Elysée on the Rue du Faubourg-Saint-Honoré, residence of the President of the French Republic, or the CHAMPS ELYSÉE; also the classical ELYSIUM.

Elysium.Entry Details: in Greek mythology the Islands of the Blest, where heroes and patriots enjoy eternal ease; Virgil places it in the lower world.

e maire del rei Jove.Entry Details: (Pr) and mother of the young king. (From a Provençal biography of Guillaume POITIERS).

[Emerson, Ralph Waldo].Entry Details: 1803-82, the American essayist and poet; called the Sage of Concord.

Emperor 9.Entry Details: see SIGISMUND V, Holy Roman Emperor.

Emperor.Entry Details: Various emperors mentioned throughout the text.

Empire.Entry Details: Various empires mentioned throughout the text, including BRITISH EMPIRE and CHINESE EMPIRE.

Empress.Entry Details: Various empresses mentioned throughout the text.

Empson.Entry Details: Sir Richard, a judge during the reign of Henry VII of England.

en casque de crystal rose les baladines.Entry Details: (Fr) in pink crystal helmets the mountebanks. (See Ballet by Stuart Merrill in Make It New, 232).

Endicott.Entry Details: John, ?1589-1665, one of SIX persons who bought the patent from Plymouth Council in England for territory on Massachusetts Bay; acted as first governor of the colony (1628) until Winthrop took charge (1630); served as assistant governor, deputy governor, and governor at various times (1630-64).

En fait de commerce ce (Bonaparte) est u.Entry Details: (Fr) as regards commerce this (Bonaparte) is a scatterbrain. (See: J. Q. Adams, Diary, 67-68).

England.Entry Details: References to England throughout the text.

Ennemosor.Entry Details: Joseph, 1787-1854, author of Geschichte der Magie, Leipzig, 1844.

En son Palais divers ateliers.Entry Details: (Fr) In his Palace various workrooms. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, I, 93).

Entha hieron Poseidonos.Entry Details: (Gr) There (is) a temple of POSEIDON. (See The Periplus of Hanno, 4).

Entrez donc, mais entrez, / c'est la mai.Entry Details: (Fr) Enter then, go on in, it is everyone's house.

Ephesus.Entry Details: one of the principal Ionian cities on the coast of Asia Minor.

Epictetus.Entry Details: fl. 60-140, the Stoic philosopher, author of the Lectures or Diatribai on the values of endurance and abstention.

(Ep1 purgo) peur de la hasle.Entry Details: (Gr) (upon the wall) (Fr) Fear of the (O Fr) sunburn. (See: Appendix A; Literary Essays, 254).

E po1 ha vishtu una volpe.Entry Details: (It) And then he saw a fox.

e poi 10 dissi alla sorella/ della pasto.Entry Details: (It) and then I asked the sister/ of the little shepherdess of the hogs/ and these Americans?/ do they behave well? and she: not very well/ not very well at all/ and I: worse than the Germans? / and she the same.

Eppes.Entry Details: John Wayles, 1773-1823, nephew and son-in-law of Thomas JEFFERSON.

e quel remir.Entry Details: (Pr) into which I gaze. (See: Arnaut Daniel: XII: Doutz brais et critz.

Era, the..Entry Details: the Era Fascista. proclaimed by MUSSOLINI in 1922, lasted until 1943.

Erard.Entry Details: Érard, a make of piano; Sebastien Erard, 1752-1831, French maker of musical instruments.

Erebus.Entry Details: in Greek mythology a place of darkness in the underworld through which souls pass on the way to Hades.

\"Ere he his goddis brocht in Latio\".Entry Details: from Gavin Douglas, Aeneid. (See: Literary Essays, 245).

Eri men al de kudoniai.Entry Details: (Gr) In the spring the quinces. (See: Appendix A).

Eripuit caelo fulmen.Entry Details: (L) He snatched the lightning from the sky. (Note: the original, Turgot's epigram on Benjamin Franklin, reads, Eripuit coelo fulmen; mox sceptra tyrannis, see: John Adams, Works, I, 662).

Erizio, Marc.Entry Details: prob. a member of the Consiglio dei DIECI, Venice.

[Ermentrude].Entry Details: d. 869, first wife of CHARLES II of France (Charles le Chauve). She was noted for her ornamental needlework, and Johannes Scotus ERIGENA compared her with ATHENA.

Erneung des Religiosen Lebens.Entry Details: Erneurung des religiosen lebens (Ger) Revival of Religious Life. (See: Wilhelm BAUR).

Eros.Entry Details: the god of love, son of APHRODITE.

err' un'imbecille; ed ha imbecillito/ 11.Entry Details: (It) he was an imbecile; and he has made imbecile/ the world.

Eso es luto, / ml marido es muerto.Entry Details: (Sp) That is mourning, / my husband is dead.

Esperanza.Entry Details: Espéranza, Duchess of Monte Putina, one of the main characters in Rene CREVEL's Les Pieds dans le plat (1933).

Estaing.Entry Details: Comte Jean Baptiste Charles Henri Hector d', 1729-94, French naval commander who led a squadron aiding the Americans during the Revolutionary War.

[Este].Entry Details: variant spelling for Ateste, commune in N Italy.

Este, the.Entry Details: a reference to the Este family.

[Este, Alberto d'].Entry Details: 1347-1393, father of Niccolò d'ESTE; Marchese and Vicar of Ferrara.

[Este, Alfonso d'].Entry Details: 1476-1534, Alfonso I, third husband of Lucrezia BORGIA, became third Duke of Ferrara in 1505 and made it a center of the arts.

[Este, Borso d'].Entry Details: 1413-71, son of Niccolò d'ESTE; Lord of Ferrara and a patron of learning; he was unable to keep peace between Sigismondo MALATESTA and Federigo d'URBINO.

(Este, Ercole d'].Entry Details: 1431-1505, Ercole I, second duke of Ferrara, son of Niccolò d'ESTE; patron of Ariosto.

[Este, Ginevra d'].Entry Details: d. 1440, daughter of Niccolò d'ESTE; married to Sigismondo MALATESTA on 15 March 1433; when she died, PIUS II accused Sigismondo of poisoning her, but there was no conclusive evidence of such a crime.

Este, Leonello.Entry Details: Lionello d'Este, 1407-50, son of Niccolò d'ESTE, brother of Borso d'ESTE; patron of PISANELLO.

[Este, Niccolò d'].Entry Details: Nicholas III of Ferrara, 1384-1441, ruler of Ferrara, Modena, Parma, Reggio, and Milan; father of Borso, Lionello, and Ercole d'ESTE; husband of Parisina MALATESTA.

estoppel.Entry Details: (law) a bar to one's alleging or denying a fact because of his own previous action by which the contrary has been admitted, implied or determined.

\"et amava perdutamente Ixotta degli Att.Entry Details: (It) and he loved Isotta degli ATTI to distraction/ and "she was worthy of him"/ "constant in purpose/ "she was pleasing to the eyes of the prince/ "beautiful to look at" "she was liked by the people (and the honor of Italy). (See: Yriarte, Un Condottiere au XVe Siècle, p. 155: "Il a aimé éperdument Isotta et elle en était digne. La chronique de Rimini l'a caracterisé ainsi "Erat haec pulchra aspectu, plurimus dotibus locupletata, foemina belligera et fortis, et constans in proposito, grata populo et placita oculis principis. 11 Italiaeque decus epithet of Isotta, inscription on Matteo da Pasti medal (1446) reads. Isote Ariminensi Forma Et Virtute Italie Decori.

et des dettes des dites Echelles / peu d.Entry Details: (Fr) and of the debts of the said ECHELLES / in the principal decrees of the Council, December [17]66/ weapons and other implements which can only be for/ the government's account M. Saint-Libin/ well versed in the languages of the country, known by the Nabobs/..to excite him, and to follow hot upon the enemy (to the) English/ not very delicate about the means.

Et/ En l'an trentunième de son Empire/ F.Entry Details: (Fr) And/ in the thirty-first year of his Rule/ the year sixty of his age/ HONG VOU, seeing his strength weaken/ said: May virtue inspire you, TCHU-OUEN, / you faithful mandarins, cultivated people, soldiers/ Help my grandson sustain/ the dignity of this power, the weight of his office/ And as to Prince OUEN TI of the HAN in former times, / make me my funeral. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, X, 104).

Et les angloys ne povans desraciner veni.Entry Details: (O Fr) And not being able to root out the English poison of hatred.

Et les Indiens disent que Boudha.Entry Details: (Fr) and the Indians say that BUDDHA.

Et ma foi, vous savez, / tous les nerveu.Entry Details: (Fr) And really, you know, / all the nervous (or nervy) ones. No, / there is a limit; animals, animals are not/ made for that, a horse doesn't amount to much. / The men of 34, on all fours, / who cried "Mommy". But the tough guys, / at the end, there at Verdun, there were only those big boys/ and they knew exactly what the score was. / What are they worth, the generals, the lieutenant, / they weigh out at a centigramme, / they are nothing but wood. / Our captain, all shut up in himself like/ the old military engineer he was, but strong, / a strong head. There, you know, / everything, everything runs in order, and the thieves, all the vices, but the birds of prey, there were three in our company, all killed. / They went out to plunder a corpse, for nothing, they would have gone out for nothing but that. And the Jerries, you can say anything you want, / militarism etc etc... / All that, but, BUT/ the Frenchman, he fights when he has eaten. / But those poor guys/ at the end they attacked each other so they could eat, / Without orders, wild animals, they took/ prisoners, those who could speak French said:/ "Poo quah? Well, we attacked so we could eat. "/ It's the grease, the grease/ their supplies come forward at three kilometers an hour, and they creaked, they grated, could be heard five kilometers away. / (That's what finished the war.) The official list of dead: 5,000,000/ He tells you, Well yeah, it all smelled of oil. But, No! I bawled him out/ I said to him: You're a jerk! You missed the war. O Yeah! all the people with taste, I admit, / all of them in the rear/ But a guy like you! / That fellow, a guy like that! What he couldn't have taken! He was in a factory. / What, burying squad, ditch diggers, with their heads/ thrust back, looking like this, / they risked their life for a shovelful of dirt. / Must be nice and square, accurate.

Et omniformis omnis/ Intellectus est.Entry Details: (L) And every intellect is capable of assuming every shape. (See. Porphyry, De Occasionibus, the 13th chapter of which is titled: "Omnis Intellectus Est Omniformis").

Et quand lo reis Lois lo entendit/ mout.Entry Details: (O Fr) And when King Louis (LOUIS VII) heard it, he was very angry.

Et quant au troisième/ Il est tombé dans.Entry Details: (Fr) And as to the third/ he fell into the/ of his wife, (and) won't be seen again.

et/ quod publice innotescat.Entry Details: (L) and which may be publicly made known.

e theos e guné ptheggometha thasson.Entry Details: (Gr) either a goddess or a woman let us raise our voices without delay. (See: Appendix A).

Etruria.Entry Details: ancient country in central Italy; the kingdom of Etruria was erected by NAPOLEON in 1801 and incorporated into the French Empire in 1808.

Et ter flebiliter.Entry Details: (Ii) and thrice with tears. (See: Horace, Odes, IV, xil, 5).

Eulh.Entry Details: Eulh-chi-hoang-ti (Erh Shih Huang Ti) (reign: 209-206), an extremely inept emperor; he was controlled by the eunuch Chao Kao, who finally murdered him.

Euné kai philoteti ephata Kirkh.Entry Details: (Gr) Making love in bed, said CIRCE. (See: Appendix A).

eunuchs.Entry Details: the eunuchs of the imperial palace of China; whenever they gained control over an emperor, the government would decline in quality.

Europa.Entry Details: in Greek mythology the daughter of Agenor, king of Tyre, she was courted and captured by Zeus, who assumed the form of a bull.

Europa nec casta Pasiphae.Entry Details: (L) EUROPA nor chaste PASIPHAE. (See: Propertius, II, XXV111, 52).

Eurylochus.Entry Details: a member of the crew of Odysseus who, with PERIMEDES, performs the rites of sacrifice on the banks of OCEAN. (See: Odyssey, XI, 23-24).

exarchate.Entry Details: the office of an exarch, a viceroy of a Byzantine emperor.

Ex Arimino die XX Decembris/ \"Magnifice.Entry Details: (L) from RIMINI the 20th of December/ "My very excellent lord, magnificent and potent.

Excideuil.Entry Details: village of Dordogne department, SW France, near Perigreux.

ex nihil.Entry Details: (L) from nothing. (Reference is to the statement attributed to William PATERSON "the bank [ of England] hath benefit of the interest on all moneys which it creates out of nothing. 11 (See: A Visiting Card, 9).

Exso et Dno sin Dno Sigismundum Pandolfi.Entry Details: (L) Most excellent, and Lord without Lord, SIGISMONDO son of PANDOLFO/Captain General MALATESTA.

fabians.Entry Details: the Fabian Society, a group of socialists, organized in England in 1884.

facilius laudari quam invenire/ vel haud.Entry Details: (L) it is more easily praised than discovered/ or not lasting/ excellently blended in moderation/ is nevertheless brought about in unison a state by agreement/ where there is no justice, there can be no law. (For sources of these fragments see. Tacitus, Annales, IV, xxx111, 20, where text reads laudari facilius quam evenire, vel S1 evenit, haud diuturna esse potest, Cicero, De Re Publica, II, xxui, 41, where text reads statu esse optimo confusa mo- dice Cicero, De Re Publica, II, xl11, 69, and Cicero, De Re Publica, III, Fragmenta, where text reads Ub1 justitia vera non est, nec jus potest esse, a quotation from St. Augustine, De Civitate De1, XIX, 21; see also: John Adams, Works, IV, 294-296).

Factory Act.Entry Details: the British act passed in 1825, shortening the hours of child labor, amended (1829, 1831) specifically to regulate child employment in cotton mills. (See John HOBHOUSE).

\"Fades light from sea-crest, and brough.Entry Details: from Sappho. (See: C. R. Haines, Sappho: the poems and fragments, 84-86).

Faece Romuli non Platonis republica.Entry Details: (L) in the dregs of ROMULUS, not in PLATO's republic. (See: Cicero: Epp. ad Atticum II, 1, 8).

Faenza.Entry Details: town in Romagna, N central Italy; ruled by the MANFREDIs (14th and 15th centuries).

Fa Han.Entry Details: prob. invention; poss. Fa Hiän, an early Chinese pilgrim to India who is remembered for his travelogues.

faire passer ces affaires/ avant ceux de.Entry Details: (Fr) to make these matters come/ before those of the nation.

Fa me hora tagliar la testa/ dapoi cosi.Entry Details: (It) now let my head be cut off/ being that so quickly you decapitated my UGO.

Fan-chungin.Entry Details: (Fan Shun-jen) fl. AD 1069, Chinese minister sent by Emperor CHIN-TSONG to inspect the progress of OUANG-NGAN-CHE's reforms in the province of SHENSI; Fan-chungin complained of the new regime because it did away with the form of government that had always been in China.

[Fang-koue-tchin].Entry Details: (Fang Kuei-chên) fl. AD 1358, a Chinese pirate during the reign of CHUNTI. He operated a fleet of junks off the South China coast and added his bit to the general rebellion which ended the Mongol dynasty.

Fan-koual.Entry Details: (Fan Kua1) d. BC 189, a dog-butcher of P'e1 (in modern Kiangsu) who early attached himself to the fortunes of LIEOU-PANG and became one of his advisers when he attained the rank of emperor. When Emperor Kao was old, he shut himself in the palace; Fan-kouai found him sleeping pillowed on a eunuch. Fan-koual burst into tears and said: "Sire, think of Chao Kao! (See EULH). The emperor then got up and went back to work.

Fan-kuang.Entry Details: (Fan Kuang) fl AD 1450, Chinese commander in the imperial troops defending Peiping from the Mongol warriors

[Fan-li].Entry Details: (Fan L1) fl. BC 474, Chinese minister of Kou Chien, Prince of YUEI State. Kou Chien had been attacked by the troops of Wu some years before and Fan-l1 urged him to take revenge, he did so and was victorious.

Fano.Entry Details: town of the Marches, E central Italy, once in the possession of the MALATESTAs.

Fano Caesaris.Entry Details: poss. reference to the triumphal arch of AUGUSTUS in FANO, poss. merely reference to fact that Fano was once a Roman settlement.

[Fan-tchin].Entry Details: (Fan Chen) fl. AD 484, Chinese intellectual, one of a group that gathered about Hs1ao Tzu-liang, son of Emperor OU-TI. The prince was a BUDDHIST, but Fan-tchin took it upon himself to discourse on the methods which the Buddhist monks (BONZES) used to deceive the people.

Fan Tsuyu.Entry Details: (Fan Tsu-yu) fl. AD 1084, Chinese historian in the court of Emperor CHIN-TSONG; one of those who helped SSE- MA-KOUANG compile The TSE-TCHI-TONG-KIEN.

Farben works.Entry Details: the I. G. Farben (Interessen Gemeinschaft Farbenindustrie Aktiengesellschaft) works, German chemical and dye cartel, officially organized as a monopoly in 1925 at Frankfurt-on-Main.

Farinatis, Picus de.Entry Details: a son of Farinata degli UBERTI.

Fasa.Entry Details: a tribe of heroes in N Africa. (See: Frobenius, Erlebte Erdteile).

[Fates].Entry Details: the three goddesses supposed to determine the course of human life; their names were Clotho (the Spinner), Lachesis (the Disposer of Lots) and Atropos (the Inflexible).

[Federal Constitutional Convention].Entry Details: the convention which met at Philadelphia in 1787, the Convention was to examine and improve the Articles of Confederation, but the Articles were quickly recognized to be inadequate, and the Convention abandoned them and wrote the CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.

federalists.Entry Details: supporters of U. S. CONSTITUTION, anti-Jeffersonians.

Federal Reserve banks.Entry Details: the United States Federal Reserve Bank, organized to serve as a bank of reserve and rediscount for member banks (all national banks and many state banks and trust companies). Federal reserve banks have the power to issue currency.

Feigenbaum.Entry Details: probably an acquaintance of Pound in Philadelphia, c. 1908.

Fe1-tsei.Entry Details: Fe1-tsé (Fe1 Tzu) fl. BC 900, an ancestor of Yih, an official of the great CHUN. Fe1-tse1 was given charge of Emperor Hiao-wang's studs. When he was appointed head of his clan, there was a great fall of hail in SHENSI, so that oxen and horses died in great numbers and the Han river was frozen, these seemed to be unlucky omens for the CHOU dynasty. Fe1-tse1 was given a small portion of land in Kansu province, the chief town of which was Ts'in, thus he became the Prince of Ts'in (Ch'in).

Fen-yang.Entry Details: (Fen Yang) fl. BC 520, Chinese general and counselor of KING WANG (BC 544-519), and of his grandson, KING-OUANG.

[Ferdinand I of Austria].Entry Details: 1793-1875, emperor of Austria (1835-48); son and successor of Emperor Francis II. Subject to fits of insanity, he was dominated by a council led by Metternich, which ruled in his name; he was forced to abdicate (1848) in favor of his nephew, FRANZ JOSEPH.

[Ferdinand I of Naples].Entry Details: 1458-94, natural son and successor to ALFONSO V of Aragon and Naples.

Ferdinand I of Naples and Sicily.Entry Details: 1751-1825, King of Naples (1759-1806; 1815-25) as Ferdinand IV; because he remained hostile to NAPOLEON, he fled to Palermo while the French established the short-lived Parthenopean Republic at Naples (1799); in 1806 he fled to Sicily where he ruled as Ferdinand III while Naples was ruled by Joseph Bonaparte and Murat; he was restored to the throne of Naples in 1815 and was made king of the Two Sicilies in 1816 as Ferdinand I.

[Ferdinand I of Tuscany].Entry Details: Ferdinand de'MEDICI, 1549-1609, Grand Duke of Tuscany (1587-1609); responsible for the founding of the real strength and prosperity of the grand duchy.

[Ferdinand II of Tuscany].Entry Details: Ferdinand de'Medic1, 1610-1670, Grand Duke of Tuscany (1620-70), patron of arts and letters.

[Ferdinand III of Tuscany].Entry Details: 1769-1824, Grand Duke of Tuscany (1790-99, 1814-24) and Archduke of Austria.

Ferrara, paradiso dei sarti, 'feste stom.Entry Details: (It) Ferrara, heaven of the tailors, 'disgusting festivals'.

[Feyankou].Entry Details: (Fe1 Yang-ku) d. AD 1701, Chinese grand-general in the service of Emperor KANG-HI. His greatest military feat was his part in the campaigns against KALDAN, the chief of the ELEUTES. In 1696 he pursued Kaldan's forces through the Gobi desert and defeated them at Chaomoto, to the north of the desert. In 1697 Kaldan committed suicide and his followers submitted to the emperor all the country east of the Ordos.

Fidascz.Entry Details: (Fidesco) - Pound's note in Cantos 1972 identifies him as a person from Pistoia.

Figlia di Jorio, La.Entry Details: (It) Jorio's Daughter, a play (1904) by D'ANNUNZIO.

Finlandia.Entry Details: a tone poem (1900) by the Finnish composer, Sibelius.

fin oreille.Entry Details: prob. (Fr) fine oreille: a good ear.

[Firdausi].Entry Details: fl. 940-1020, Persian poet, author of the SHAH NAMAH, the great Persian epic, his real name was Abul Kasim Mansur.

Flanders.Entry Details: formerly a country in the Low Countries; now divided between Belgium and France.

Flassans.Entry Details: Jean Baptiste Gaeton de Roxis de Flassan, 1760-1845, French diplomat and historian; author of Histoire Générale et Raisonée de la Diplomatie Française (1808).

Fleet Prison.Entry Details: a debtor's prison on Fleet Street, London.

Fleta.Entry Details: name of a Latin textbook on English law, Fleta, seu Commentarius Iuris Anglicani (c. 1290), believed to have been written in FLEET PRISON by one of the corrupt judges imprisoned by Edward I.

Flora.Entry Details: an old Italian deity of fertility and flowers.

Floradora.Entry Details: a musical comedy written by Leslie Stuart (1900), famous for the Floradora Sextette which sang and danced the hit number of the show, "Tell Me Pretty Maiden."

Florence.Entry Details: capital of FIRENZE province, Tuscany, central Italy.

Florian's.Entry Details: a restaurant in the Piazza di San Marco, Venice.

Florida.Entry Details: the state on the extreme SE tip of the United States, formerly a Spanish possession.

Foé.Entry Details: the name of BUDDHA and more commonly the name given to Buddhist priests, foes, foéist, in French transliteration.

Folies, Les.Entry Details: see FOLLIES. Text reference is to the painting of Manet: Un Bar aux Folies-Bergère (1882).

Follies.Entry Details: the Folies-Bergère in the rue Richer, Paris.

Fonda.Entry Details: prob. reference to the various (It) fondamenti (streets, passageways) in Venice, possibly a contraction of (It) fondaco (warehouse), especially the Fondaco dei Turchi, 13th-century Venetian-Byzantine building on the Grand Canal, opposite the VENDRAMIN Callergi Palace.

Fong-chi.Entry Details: (Feng Shih) fl. BC 6, concubine of HAN-YUEN-TI; prominent in the reign of Emperor Han Ngai T1 (BC 6-1 AD).

Fontaney, de.Entry Details: fl. 1693, a Jesuit missionary in China.

Fonte Giusta.Entry Details: the Madonna of Fontegiusta, a church (1479) in Siena.

Ford, Ford Madox (Hueffer).Entry Details: 1873-1939, the English novelist, critic, poet, and editor.

Ford, Henry, Life of.Entry Details: prob. My Life and Work by Henry FORD (1923).

Forest.Entry Details: James, fl. 1770, a Boston merchant and Loyalist, born in Ireland.

Foresteria.Entry Details: (It) the part of a monastery (or club) where visitors are housed.

forloyn.Entry Details: a term in hunting (also forloin), meaning to leave the pack behind, used in reference to a stag or to individual hounds (See. Sonnets and Ballate of Guido Cavalcant1, 61).

Formando di disio nuova persona.Entry Details: (It) forming with desire a new person (See Sonnets and Ballate of Guido Cavalcanti, 126).

formato loc(h)o.Entry Details: (It) in a prepared place. (See: Cavalcanti. Donna m1 prega in Make It New, 366).

fornicarium ac sicarium/ proditor, rapto.Entry Details: (L) fornicator and murderer, / betrayer, rapist, incestuous, arsonist and / liver in concubinage.

Fortean Society.Entry Details: a society, organized in 1931, directed by Tiffany Thayer, devoted to the study of the works of Charles Fort (1874-1932).

Fortescue.Entry Details: Sir John, ?1394-1476?, English jurist and one of England's first constitutional lawyers.

Forti dei Marmi.Entry Details: a small Italian town, Lucca province, Italy.

Fortinbras.Entry Details: Carlo Fortebracc1, Count of Montone, Venetian condottiere during the wars between the forces of Sigismondo MALATESTA and PIUS II; he was granted 2000 ducats for enlistment of soldiers into the Venetian forces.

42nd Street.Entry Details: a major street in midtown MANHATTAN; the only tunnel on 42nd Street is a subway tube.

Foscari.Entry Details: Francesco, ?1372-1457, doge of Venice (1423-57); extended the power of Venice into northern Italy by a series of successful wars (1426-54).

Foscari, Ca'.Entry Details: the famous palace in Venice, on the Grand Canal.

Fossembrone.Entry Details: town in the Marches, central Italy, near the Metauro river.

Fou-chi.Entry Details: (Fü Shi) fl. BC 6, concubine of HAN-YUEN.

Fou Hi.Entry Details: (Fü Hsi) (reign: BC 2953-2838), the first of the Five Emperors of the legendary period of China; he taught his people to hunt, fish, and keep flocks; he invented a calendar, formed musical instruments, and developed the marriage contract.

Foundation of Regius Professors.Entry Details: Royal endowment of professorships at Oxford and Cansbridge Universities.

Fou-Pie.Entry Details: (Fü Pi) d. AD 1085, Chinese scholar and diplomat serving Emperor GIN-TSONG. In 1042 the KHITAN Tartars demanded ten counties of the empire and threatened war if the emperor refused. Fou-pie was sent to negotiate with the Khitan. Fou-pie's treaty enjoined the Khitan to keep peace and promised them a tribute each year of 100,000 ounces of silver and 100,000 pieces of silk in addition to the previous tribute promised by Emperor TCHIN-TSONG (1006). Fou-pie's treaty was humiliating to the empire, but a masterpiece of diplomacy.

Fouquet.Entry Details: prob. a resident in a New York boarding house, C. 1890. (See. Indiscretions, in Quarterly Review of Literature, V, 2 (1949) 124).

Fou-Y.Entry Details: (Fü I) fl. AD 626, Chinese minister of Emperor KAO-TSEU who petitioned that all Buddhist establishments be abolished and that all Buddhist monks and nuns be sent to their homes, he argued that Buddhism demoralized the empire by de-emphasizing the proper relationships between ruler and people, between parents and children.

Fox.Entry Details: Charles James, 1749-1806, the English statesman, sided with BURKE against NORTH's policies toward the American Colonies.

Fracastor.Entry Details: Girolamo Fracastoro, 1483-1553, Italian physician, astronomer and poet; wrote Syphilis sive Morbus Gallicus in which the hero's mother is struck by lightning while he is a child in arms.

[Franchet d'Esperey], Louis Félix Marie.Entry Details: 1856-1942, Marshal of France, commanded the French 5th Army in the battle of the Marne (1914); in 1918 he led the Allies to victory in the Balkans.

Franco.Entry Details: Francisco, 1892-, the Spanish general and dictator

franco-japanese bank.Entry Details: the Franco-Japanese Bank, closely connected with the SCHNEIDER interests.

Frankfurt.Entry Details: Frankfurt-am-Main, a manufacturing and commercial city in Wiesbaden district of Germany; location of the Institute for Cultural Morphology, founded by Leo FROBENIUS.

Franklin, Benjamin..Entry Details: 1706-90, American statesman, printer, scientist, and writer, member of the committee which drafted the DECLARATION of Independence (1776); negotiated the Treaty of Paris (1781-83) with John ADAMS and John JAY; member of the FEDERAL CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION (1787).

Franklin, Billy.Entry Details: William Temple Franklin, d. 1823, grandson of Benjamin FRANKLIN; served as secretary to his grandfather in Paris, published editions of Franklin's works (1816-19). Franklin Inn Club: 80/85: the Philadelphia literary club, founded by Dr S Weir MITCHELL (1902).

Franks.Entry Details: a group of Germanic tribes, the Western Franks consolidated into France, Eastern Franks into Germany.

Franz, Joseph.Entry Details: Emperor of Austria, 1830-1916, whose policies were contributory to the outbreak of World War I, he rejected the Serbian note after Sarajevo and declared war 28 July 1914.

Frascati.Entry Details: town in Roma province, Latium, central Italy.

Frater tamquam/ Et compater carissime, t.Entry Details: (L) like a brother/ and co-father most dear on the back (?)/ (Jo)hanni de/ (Me)dicis/ (Flor)entia (See Giovanni de' MEDICI).

Frau Burgomeister.Entry Details: the wife of the mayor of WORGL.

[Frederick II of Prussia].Entry Details: Frederick the Great, 1712-86, King of Prussia (1740-86).

[Frederick II of Sicily].Entry Details: 1272-1337, King of Sicily (1296-1337), waged war against CHARLES II of Naples (1296-1302) and against the ANGEVINS (1325).

French fleet.Entry Details: the fleet at the time of the American Revolution.

French States.Entry Details: the kingdoms established by NAPOLEON in the wake of his victories.

Fries.Entry Details: John, 21750-1818, American insurgent who opposed a federal property tax by leading a force of Pennsylvania Germans against the assessors in 1799, Fries was arrested by government troops, tried, and found guilty of treason, John ADAMS pardoned him in 1800.

Frobenus.Entry Details: Leo, 1873-1938, German archeologist and anthropologist largely interested in Africa; author of the seven-volume study, Erlebte Erdteile. (See WAGADU, FASA, GASSIR).

frog (frogs, froggies).Entry Details: slang reference to the French people.

From Fancy's dreams to active Virtue tur.Entry Details: from the verse on the tombstone of Abigail Adams. (See. John Adams, Works, I, 644).

Frontenac.Entry Details: prob. Frontignac, a French muscatel of the Pyrenees region

Fructidor.Entry Details: one of the French Revolutionary calendar months, running from 18 August to 16 September.

Frumentorum licentia/ coercita de annona.Entry Details: (L) free grain/ dole restrictions relaxed for the good of the poor/ and the rich.

Fulano, Don.Entry Details: (Sp) John Doe, a general nonexistent name.

fumée maligne.Entry Details: (Fr) evil smoke. (See. Mailla, Histoire Générale, IX, 85).

fu Nicolo/ e di qua di la del Po.Entry Details: (It) late Niccolò (d'ESTE) and on this side and the other side of the Po.

Fynje.Entry Details: see DE LA LANDE AND FYNJE.

Gabriel, Claude.Entry Details: fl 1812, a negro in the service of ALEXANDER I; on a trip to America he was insulted and even beaten by people who were offended by his official uniform (See: J. Q Adams, Diary, 96-97)

Gadsden.Entry Details: Christopher, 1724-1805, American Revolutionary leader, delegate from South Carolina to the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-76) where he supported John ADAMS' proposal to negotiate a treaty with France. He served as a brigadier general in the Continental Army (1776-78).

Gais.Entry Details: village in the Tyrol, N Italy.

Galeazzo, Sr..Entry Details: prob. a man whose daughter was seduced by Sigismondo MALATESTA, C. 1454.

Galicia.Entry Details: region and ancient kingdom, NW Spain.

Galileo.Entry Details: Galileo Galile1, 1564-1642, the Italian mathematician and astronomer.

Galla.Entry Details: Galla Placidia, 388-450, Roman empress, the Mausoleum of Galla Placidia is the church of St. Nazario Celso, Ravenna.

Gallatin.Entry Details: Abraham Alfonse Albert, 1761-1849, Swiss-born financier and statesman who came to the U. S. in 1780; served as member of the House of Representatives (1795-1801), member of committee negotiating with England after War of 1812; U. S. Minister to France (1816-23); U. S. Minister to Great Britain (1826-27).

Gallifet.Entry Details: Gaston Alexandre Auguste de Galliffet, 1830-1909, French army commander who led the charge of the Chasseurs d'Afrique at Sedan in the War of 1870.

Gallipoli.Entry Details: the Gallipoli campaign (1915) in which the Allied forces made a futile attempt to capture the Dardanelles.

Galloway.Entry Details: Joseph, ?1729-1803, American lawyer and loyalist, member of the Pennsylvania colonial legislature (1756-64; 1765-75), member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-75), where he opposed the independence of the colonies.

Gama, De.Entry Details: Vasco da Gama, 1460-1524, the Portuguese navigator.

Gamaliel.Entry Details: reference to the great teacher of Jewish law, d. AD 88; thus, any great teacher, especially of law.

Gandhi.Entry Details: Mohandas Karachand, 1869-1948, the Indian political and religious leader.

Ganelon.Entry Details: one of the Twelve Peers in the Song of Roland; prompted by jealousy, he betrayed the presence of Roland's rear-guard forces to the Moslems.

Ganna.Entry Details: locality in the African Sudan, west of Timbuctoo; second stop of the FASA in the reincarnation of WAGADU.

Garda, Lake.Entry Details: lake in E Lombardy, N Italy.

Gardiner, Sylvester.Entry Details: 1708-86, American colonial physician, he was a loyalist and fled America during the Revolution.

Gardone.Entry Details: prob. Gardone Val Trompia, a town in Brescia province, N Italy.

Gargaphia.Entry Details: Gargraphie, a vale and spring in Boeotia, sacred to ARTEMIS who was bathing there when surprised by ACTAEON. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, III, 156).

Gassir.Entry Details: Gassire, son of Nganamba FASA, king of the Fasa tribe, the story of Gassire's envy and its consequences is told in the legend collection, the Daus1, which deals with the history of WAGADU. (See. Frobenius and Fox, African Genesis, 97-110).

Gassir, Lute of.Entry Details: the introductory song to the legend collection, the Daus1. (See GASSIR).

Gaudier.Entry Details: Henri Gaudier-Brzeska, 1891-1915, Franco-Folish sculptor, killed in World War I.

Gauthier-Villars.Entry Details: Henri, 1859-1931, French novelist, essayist and biographer, generally known as "Willy".

Gautier, Judith.Entry Details: 1850-1917, French poet and novelist, daughter of Théophile GAUTIER.

Gautier, Théophile.Entry Details: 1811-72, French poet, novelist, and man of letters, leader of the Parnassian poets, author of Emaux et Camées, etc.

Gay de Lussac, rue.Entry Details: the rue Gay-Lussac, street on Left Bank, Paris.

Gazette de Madrid.Entry Details: a newspaper in Madrid, Spain, in the late 18th century.

Gemini.Entry Details: the third zodiacal constellation, represented as the twins, Castor and Pollux. The sun enters Gemini about May 21.

Gemistus, Georgius.Entry Details: fl. early 15th century, Greek Platonic philosopher, sometimes called Plethon, who led Cosimo de' MEDICI to found the Florentine Academy for classical studies; Sigismondo MALATESTA brought his remains back from the MOREA and placed them in the TEMPIO.

Genet.Entry Details: Edmé-Jacques, d. 1781, head of the Bureau of Correspondence of the French Department of Foreign Affairs (1762); he was a close friend of John ADAMS when Adams was in France, and he supported American independence.

Genghis Khan.Entry Details: (also Jenghiz or Chingiz) 1162-1227, Mongol emperor. His personal name was Temougin (Temuchin) and his imperial title Tai-Tsou (T'a1 Tsú). He proclaimed himself emperor of the Mongols in 1206. Through a series of wars with the various Tartar tribes (mainly the KHITAN and NUTCHÉ) he became by 1214 master of all the territory north of Hwang-ho, except for Feiping, the capital of the KIN dynasty of the Nutché, he conquered Korea and by 1221 controlled much of central Asia. During his career of conquest he established the power of the Mongol in Asia.

Genji.Entry Details: central character in Lady Murasaki's Tale of Genji, also mentioned in some of the Noh plays. Historically, the Genji, or Minamoto, were a Japanese feudal clan. (See Translations, 231).

Georgia.Entry Details: the southern state of the U.S.

Gerbillon.Entry Details: Jean-François, 1654-1707, Jesuit missionary in China. He arrived in Peiping in 1688, and his talents at once impressed Emperor KANG-HI. He served with PÉREIRA on the commission to negotiate a border treaty between China and Russia in 1689, the Treaty of NIPCHOU. He was a skilled linguist and mathematician and wrote an account of his journeys in Tartary.

German-Burgundian female.Entry Details: a noblewoman assaulted and killed while on the way to Rome for the Jubilee (1450). Sigismondo MALATESTA was thought to have done it, but the evidence was not conclusive.

German princes.Entry Details: the petty princes of the various German states, C. 1780.

Gerry, Elbridge.Entry Details: 1744-1814, American statesman; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1776-81; 1782-85), signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, delegate to the FEDERAL CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION (1787), member of the XYZ mission to France, Governor of Massachusetts (1810, 1811).

Gervais.Entry Details: brand name of a French dairy company.

Geryon(e).Entry Details: (1) the three-headed or three-bodied monster, living on the island of Erythia, killed by HERACLES, (2) the symbol of fraud and guardian of the eighth circle of hell in the Inferno, sometimes a symbol of usury, Violence against nature and art, etc. (See Inferno, 17).

Geschichte und Lebensbilder.Entry Details: (Ger) history and pictures (images) from (of) life. (See Wilhelm BAUR).

Gesell.Entry Details: Silvio, 1862-1930, German merchant and economist known especially for his emphasis on the theory of velocity of money circulation and his advocacy of stamped paper currency as a medium of exchange, author of Die Verstaatlichung des Geldes (1891).

Gethsemane Trebizond Petrol.Entry Details: poss. pseudonym for the Anglo-Persian O1l Company, in which ZAHAROFF had an interest.

Gettysburg.Entry Details: the battle of Gettysburg, June-July 1863, a major battle in the Civil War at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.

ghazel.Entry Details: (Arab) ghazila: a form of Persian love poetry in couplets riming on the same sound: aa, ba, ca, etc.

Gignetei kalon.Entry Details: (Gr) a beautiful thing is born. (See: Appendix A).

Giles.Entry Details: William Branch, 1762-1830, American statesman; member of House of Representatives (1790-98); opposed the founding of the First Bank of the United States and brought charges of corruption against HAMILTON (1793); the charges were dismissed; U. S. Senator (1804-1815).

Gin Cheou.Entry Details: poss. reference to the Ch'en dynasty (557-89).

Gin Tsong.Entry Details: (Jen Tsung) (reign: 1023-64). He had to contend with internal rebellions and invasions which weakened the empire; in 1042 he was forced to make a humiliating peace with the KHI- TAN Tartars to keep them quiet. A patron of literature, he encouraged a golden age of Chinese literature in which many of the most noted poets, historians and scholars wrote.

Gin-tsong.Entry Details: (Jen Tsung or Ayuli Palpata) (reign 1312-21). The eighth emperor of the Yuan dynasty. An able administrator, well read in Confucius and Buddha and averse to war, he tried to improve the government and abolished those abuses brought to his notice, but the practice of giving the highest government posts to Mongols was not effective and the people were oppressed. He enacted sumptuary laws and established regular examinations for officials.
(Jen Tsung) (reign 1425-1426), came to the throne at the age of forty-seven and ruled only a little over nine months.

Gionfiglioli, Horatio.Entry Details: prob. member of the BALIA of Siena, 1622.

Giovanna.Entry Details: servant in a Venetian house where Pound used to stay.

Gisors.Entry Details: town, 20 miles NW of Paris; medieval capital of the Vexin district, France.

[Giustinian, Bernardo].Entry Details: Venetian ambassador to PIUS II, charged to press for peace between the Pope and the MALATESTA family.

Glanville.Entry Details: Ranulf de, d. 1190, English statesman and jurist; advisor to Henry II of England.

Glaucus.Entry Details: Glaucus of Anthedon, he became immortal by a magic herb, then for some reason he leaped into the sea and became a sea-god and was famous for his gift of prophecy. The name is also an epithet of the sea.

Glielmo ciptadin.Entry Details: (It) Guglielmo citizen. (Reference is to the inscription over the altar of the Cathedral of Ferrara.)

Gluck.Entry Details: Christoph Willibald, 1714-87, German composer, best known for his operas, IPHIGÉNIE en Tauride, etc.

Goah.Entry Details: Goath, a locality near or in Jerusalem.

Goedel.Entry Details: prob. a German soldier whom Pound met when he hitchhiked north from Rome after the 8 September 1943 armistice.

Goito.Entry Details: name of castle and town, ten miles from Mantua; birthplace of SORDELLO.

Golden Roof.Entry Details: reference to the church of La Daurade, Toulouse, France. The Italian name, La Dorata ( = the Golden One).

golden wand.Entry Details: the golden wand of TIRESIAS. (See: Odyssey, XI, 91.

Gold Mirror.Entry Details: the Kin-king (Chin-ching) or The Mirror of Gold, a work by the emperor, TAI-TSONG. This work may be the same as Tai-tsong's NOTES ON CONDUCT.

Goncourt.Entry Details: Edmond Louis Antoine de, 1822-96, and Jules Alfred Huot de, 1830-70, French novelists and historians. (See. ACADÉMIE GONCOURT).

gonfaron/ et leurs fioles chargies de vi.Entry Details: (Fr) poss. gan-falon: banner/ and their flasks full of wine.

Gonzaga.Entry Details: prob. Ercole GONZAGA; poss. Francesco GONZAGA.

Gonzaga, Carlo.Entry Details: 15th-century soldier of Mantua, member of the Gonzaga family, rulers of Mantua; he betrayed Milan by admitting to the city the troops of Francesco SFORZA.

Gonzaga.Entry Details: Ercole, 1505-63, cardinal of the Roman Church and regent of the Duchy of Mantua; a patron of the arts and learning, presided over the Council of Trent.

Gonzaga, Fran°.Entry Details: Gian Francesco, d. 1519, Lord of Mantua (1484-1519).

Gonzaga, Luig1.Entry Details: 1267-1360, founder of the house of Gonzaga, which ruled Mantua from 1328 to 1708, Luigi became captain-general of Mantua in 1328.

Good Hope.Entry Details: the cape at the tip of South Africa.

Goodwin.Entry Details: Sir Francis, principal of the Goodwin Case (1604) in which Parliament asserted its right to be the sole judge of the election returns of its own members.
