Oleron.Entry Details: Ile d'Oléron, an island in the Bay of Biscay, noted for its Laws of Oleron, a medieval code of maritime laws which forms the basis of modern maritime law.

Oliver.Entry Details: Andrew, 1706-44, secretary and lieutenant-governor of Massachusetts Colony (1756-71); stamp officer for the STAMP ACT in Massachusetts. Oliver advocated the dispatch of British troops to America and the prosecution of Samuel ADAMS for his political agitation.

Peter, 1713-91, a Massachusetts loyalist. As chief justice of Massachusetts Colony (1771-76) Oliver agreed to accept special monetary grants from the English Crown to the Massachusetts judiciary, and this action prompted the legislature to impeach him, however, Governor Thomas HUTCHINSON blocked the proceedings. In 1774 several Massachusetts grand juries refused to serve under Oliver because of his loyalist sympathies.

Olivet.Entry Details: the Mount of Olives, east of Jerusalem.

olofans, 1'.Entry Details: Olifant, Roland's horn. (See: The Song of Roland).

Oltrepassimo.Entry Details: prob. pseudonym for Prince Filippo-Massimiliano Massimo, 1843-1915, created first Prince Lancellotti (1865) by PIUS IX; from his half-brother, Prince Camillo-Carlo-Alberto Massimo, he purchased the DISCOBOLUS.

omnia, quae sunt, lumina sunt.Entry Details: (L) everything that exists is light. (Possibly suggested by Grosseteste, De luce seu de inchoatione formarum, ed. Baur, 57, where text reads omnia esse unum ab unis lucis perfectione ea, quae sunt multa, esse multa ab ipsius lucis diversa multiplicatione).

Ongla, oncle.Entry Details: (Pr) Nail, uncle. (See: Arnaut Daniel, Loferm voler qu'el cor m'intra).

Ohis.Entry Details: Don Luis de, Spanish minister at Washington in 1819; negotiated the treaty between the US and Spain which gave Florida to the US. When Spain ratified the treaty (1821) there was much popular sentiment against Spain in America.

Orage.Entry Details: Alfred Richard, 1873-1934, English journalist, editor of the New Age.

Oranienbaum.Entry Details: town in the Leningrad Region of Soviet Russia, was an imperial residence 1727-1914.

Ora vela, ora a remi, sino ad ora di ves.Entry Details: (It) Now sailing, now rowing, until the (hour of) sunset. (Possibly from Luchino dal CAMPO).

Orbe.Entry Details: town in Vaud Canton, W. Switzerland, on the Orbe River.

Orbem bellis, urbem gabellis, Urbanus oc.Entry Details: (L) URBAN VIII filled the world with wars, the city with taxes.

Orbetello.Entry Details: town of Grosseto province in Tuscany.

oricalchi.Entry Details: (L) of copper. (See: Homeric Hymn VI To Aphrodite, 9).

Orleans.Entry Details: town of the Loiret department, Ncentral France.

ormoulu.Entry Details: ormolu, brass made to imitate gold.

Orsini.Entry Details: Count Aldobrando Orsini, fl. 1440, Signore of Pitigliano.

Ortes.Entry Details: Ortos (Ordos) a Tartar tribe occupying the territory of Ordos, a desert region south of the Hwang Ho in Suryuan province, central Inner Mongolia.

O se credesse.Entry Details: (It) or if he would believe. (See: Varchi, Storia Fiorentino, III, 262).

O se morisse, credesse caduto da sè.Entry Details: (It) or if he would die, believed fallen by himself. (See Varchi, Storia Fiorentino, III, 262: o che egli non morisse non S1 credesse lui esser caduto da se.

Ostend.Entry Details: port city of W Flanders province, N Belgium.

ostendit incitatque. Vir autem.Entry Details: see DE LIBRO CHI-KING SIC CENSO

Oswald.Entry Details: Richard, 1705-84, English statesman. In 1782 he was given authority to make peace with the American colonies at the Paris peace negotiations, however, he did not sign the definitive Treaty of Versailles (3 September 1783).

O sweet and lovely/ o Lady be good..Entry Details: from the song by George Gershwin, Oh, Lady Be Good.

oth fugol outbaer.Entry Details: the line should read SUMNE FUGOL OTHBAER.

Otis.Entry Details: Samuel Allyne, 1740-1814, American statesman, member of the Constitutional Convention (1784), Secretary of the U. S. Senate (1789-1814).

Otis, James.Entry Details: 1725-83, American lawyer and patriot, advocate general of Boston (1756-61) but resigned in protest against the issuing of writs of assistance, head of the Massachusetts Committee of Correspondence (1764), opposed the STAMP ACT and organized the Stamp Congress (1765); also wrote on Latin and Greek prosody.

Otreus, King.Entry Details: legendary king of Phrygia, when APHRODITE lay with ANCHISES, she told him that her father was King Otreus, for she wished to keep her identity a secret. (See. Homeric Hymn V to Aphrodite, 111ff).

O troubled reflection/ O Throat, O throb.Entry Details: from Whitman, Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking.

Ou.Entry Details: (Wu) one of the THREE KINGDOMS; the kingdom of Wu controlled the territory south of the Yangtze.

Qua-chi.Entry Details: (Wa Shih) fl. AD 1559, a princess of Kwangsi province; she led Chinese troops against Japanese pirates that were attacking the southeast coast of China.

Ouang Chi.Entry Details: (Wang Shih) fl. AD 15, he and his five brothers were of the family of Wang Mang, the Usurper (reign 9-23).

(Wang Shih) d. AD 1297, wife of KANOUEN, commander of Tchang-tcheou. Rather than become the wife of TCHIN-TIAO-YEN, the murderer of her husband, Ouang Chi leapt into the funeral pyre of Kanouen. Emperor TIMOUR was much impressed by the deed and built a memorial for her.

Ouangchin.Entry Details: (Wang Shen) fl. AD 1403, a Buddhist priest serving in the temple of Chin-lo-koan, outside the city of Nanking.

Ouang-mi.Entry Details: (Wang M1) fl. AD 107, a mandarin who attempted to bribe YANG-TCHIN.

Ouang-Ngan-ché.Entry Details: (Wang An-shih) 1021-86, became confidential advisor and minister of state to Emperor CHIN-TSONG (1069). He and the emperor began reforms based on Ouang's new and "more correct" interpretations of the Classics. state administration of commerce, state support for farmers, compulsory military service, a state system of barter, a new land tax system. In the face of much opposition, the emperor put Ouang's reforms into practice, but Ouang tried to move too rapidly and lived to see all his reforms abolished. After his death he was disgraced and his tablet removed from the Confucian Temple.

Ouang-po.Entry Details: (Wang Po) d. AD 959, a statesman, mathematician, and personal counselor to Emperor CHI-TSONG.

Ouang Siaopo.Entry Details: (Wang Hsiao-po) fl. AD 993, a man of the people who roused Szechwan province to revolt against their governor in 993. There was little money in the province, since the conquering SUNG troops had carried it away a few years before; the mandarins were fleecing the people, the rich were buying up small farms and depriving the poor of land and food. Imperial troops soon put down the rebellion, and Emperor TAI-TSONG appointed a governor who improved the condition of the poor.

Ouang-siun.Entry Details: (Wang Hsün) fl. AD 280, a general serving Emperor TCIN-OU-TI; engaged in campaigns against the kingdom of Wu, one of the THREE KINGDOMS.

Ouang tchi.Entry Details: Ouang-tchu (Wang Chu) d. AD 1282, chief officer of the city of Peiping. He led the conspiracy to assassinate AHAMA, the chief minister of KUBLAI KHAN; Ouang-tchu lured Ahama to the palace late at night and killed him with an iron mace. Kubla1 had Ouang executed.

[Ouang-tsai-gin].Entry Details: (Wang Tsai-Jen) d. AD 847, favorite concubine of Emperor OU-TSONG.

[Ouang-ts1uen-pin].Entry Details: (Wang Chuon-pin) fl. AD 965, a general serving Emperor TCHAO-KOUANG; he was in charge of the expedition which succeeded in overcoming the HEOU-CHOU.

Ouang Yeou.Entry Details: (Wang Yeou) fl. AD 9 21, a rebel commander of the troops of LI-TSUN-HIU, Prince of Tein, he invited the Khitan Tartars to attack some cities of China, which they did.

Quan L1.Entry Details: (Wan L1), title of the reign of Emperor CHIN-TSONG.

Quan-soui!.Entry Details: (Ch) (Wan-sui). Ten thousand years. (One of the forms of address to the Emperor of China).

Quantse.Entry Details: prob. Ouantçe (Wan Tzu) fl. AD 1291, one of KUBLAI KHAN's ministers of state.

Ouanyen.Entry Details: (Wan-yen), family name of the rulers of the KIN dynasty of the NUTCHÉ Tartars.

Quei.Entry Details: (Wei), a principality in the general region of the modern Sian, a city of SHENSI province, NE central China, on the We river where it joins the Hwang Ho.

Quei-Kao.Entry Details: (Wei Kao) d. AD 805, a general of the imperial troops who won significant victories over the Tartars. As governor of a province for 21 years he gained more fame, for during that time the people of his province paid exactly the tax demanded by the emperor from the province-- and no more.

Quei-Lie.Entry Details: Ouei-lié-ouang (We1-Lieh Wang) (reign: 425-401), during the reign of this emperor nothing much happened, except that the tripods of YU began making noises- which meant that the end of the TCHEOU dynasty was near.

Quei-Tching.Entry Details: (We Cheng) d. AD 643, an astute minister of Emperor TAI-TSONG.

Quen.Entry Details: Ouen-knang-hien (Wên-chiang-hsien), a town in SZECHWAN province.

Quen Kong.Entry Details: (Wên Kung) d. BC 609, Prince of LOU; a benevolent and capable ruler.

Quen ti.Entry Details: (Wen T1) (reign: 424-453). In spite of the opposition of the state of OUEI, he extended the power of the emperor over much territory. He was fond of literature and the arts and paid attention to education by establishing national colleges.

(Ouen-ti].Entry Details: (Wen ti) (reign: 581-605), first emperor of the Sui dynasty (589-618). He commanded that no man should be put to death before his case had been reported three times; however, this led to great government corruption, for it gave a wide margin of safety to corrupt mandarins Because the emperor was uneducated, he had great contempt for scholars and classical education, he preferred simple and direct language to the rhetoric of the Classics.

Ouen Tiensiang.Entry Details: (Wên T'ien-hsiang) 1236-83, one of the most patriotic men in Chinese history; he served the last five emperors of the Southern SUNG dynasty as minister and general. All his efforts to stem the Mongol invasions and preserve the dynasty failed, and when the dynasty fell he was taken prisoner (1279). Because he would not pledge his loyalty to the Mongols, he was executed by KUBLAI KHAN.

Quen-Tsong.Entry Details: (Wen Tsung) (reign: 827-41). He began his reign by cutting government expenditures, dismissing three thousand women from the royal harem, and giving audiences to his ministers every other day; but he lacked firmness of purpose, and soon the power of the court was usurped by the eunuchs. At this time the eunuchs became a national danger, but all efforts to get rid of them failed.

Quen yan Tchin hochang.Entry Details: Ouanyen-tchin-ho-chang (Wan-yen Chen Ho-shang) d. AD 1232, prince royal of the KIN dynasty and an officer of the Kin troops during the battles between the Kin and the Mongols.

Ou-heou.Entry Details: (Wu Hou) 625-705, one of the concubines of Emperor TAI TSONG, after his death she became the empress of KAO-TSONG in 656, and for the next forty years she was one of the most important figures in Chinese political history. Cruel and unscrupulous, she controlled two emperors and became virtual ruler of the Empire. She forced her husband to make her co-ruler (they were known as 'The Two Holy Ones') and finally took over all his power. During the years 684-705 her son TCHONG-TSONG was nominally the emperor, but the period 1S often known as the reign of Empress Ou-heou.

Ou-Kiar.Entry Details: (Wu Ch'ieh) fl. AD 1135, a captain of the imperial troops who served Emperor Kao Tsung (reign. 1127-63).

Ousan.Entry Details: Ou-san-koue1 (Wu San-kuel) d. AD 1678, a commander of the imperial forces during the last years of the MING dynasty. In 1643 Ou-san-koue1 received news that Peiping had fallen to the rebel LI-TSE-TCHING and that the emperor had committed suicide, after making conditions about the treatment of the Chinese, Ou-san gave his allegiance to the Manchus. As a result, the Manchus captured Peiping and established their dynasty over China.

où sont les heurs.Entry Details: (Fr) where are the (O Fr) good times. (Variation of Villon: Où sont les neiges d'antan).

Ou-tchao.Entry Details: Ou-tchao-y (Wu Chao-1) fl. AD 953, wishing to start a college, he requested permission of the Prince of Chou to have the SHU CHING and the SHIH CHING printed (953), the permission was granted.

Ou Ti.Entry Details: (Wu T1) (reign: 483-94), he paid attention to the laws of the kingdom and cut down the number of retainers at court; however, while he worried about rebellion within the Empire, he forgot to consider the threat of the rising power of the kingdom of OUEI.

(Wu Ti) (reign: 503-50) founder of the LIANG dynasty; a good emperor who helped his people during famine and purged the court of corruption. He became a Buddhist and imported three thousand Buddhist priests to the capital; during his reign more than thirteen thousand Buddhist temples were built in the Empire. In 528 Ou-t1 became a Buddhist monk, but soon his ministers asked him to attend to the business of the Empire, and he was absolved of his vows.

Outline of the Historical View of the Pr.Entry Details: Esquisse d'un tableau historique des progrès de l'esprit humain (1801-04) by CONDORCET, in which he traces the human development through nine epochs to the French Revolution and predicts that the tenth epoch will be the ultimate perfection of man.

Ou-Tsong.Entry Details: (Wu Tsung) (reign: 841-47). His one important decree was that all Taoist and Buddhist priests and nuns in the Empire should return to their homes and stop living in idleness and immorality.

Ou Tsong.Entry Details: (Wu Tsung) (reign 1506-1521), a weak and childish emperor, after he had been persuaded to execute the eunuch LIEOU-KIN, he chose KIANG-PING, a military adventurer, as his chief advisor. Ou-tsong came to the throne as a minor, but as he grew older he did not grow wiser. He devoted himself to leisure and frivolity and left no heir.

Ou-yen.Entry Details: prob. a confusion of Ou-han (Wu Han) and Kou-yen (Ku Yen), both fl. AD 26, and both were Chinese generals who were created Princes of the Empire, they were especially successful in the wars against the brigands. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, III, 285).

Overyssel.Entry Details: Overijssel, a province in E Netherlands.

O VO1 che siete in piccioletta barca..Entry Details: (It) oh you who are on a very small boat. (See: Paradiso, 2, 1).

O woman shapely as a swan.Entry Details: from Padraic Colum, I Shall Not Die for Thee in Collected Poems, 134.

Paddock.Entry Details: Adino, a Boston coachmaker who was John ADAMS' captain when Adams served in the Boston civilian night watch just after the Boston Massacre (5 March 1770).

Paichen.Entry Details: - Sina-pacheng (Hsina-plaishêng), prob. the modern city of Sining (or Hsining) in Tsinghai province, W central China.

Paine, Robert.Entry Details: - Robert Treat Paine, 1731-1814, American jurist, member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774-78) and signer of the DECLARATION of Independence, judge of the Massachusetts supreme court (1790-1804).

Palace of the Doges.Entry Details: in the Piazza di San Marco, Venice.

[ Palaeologus, John].Entry Details: 1391-1448, John VIII, ruler of the Eastern Roman Empire (1425-1448); to obtain western aid against the Turks he appeared at the Councils of Ferrara and Florence (1438-39).

Palgrave.Entry Details: Francis Turner, 1824-97, English poet and critic, professor of poetry at Oxford (1885-95); edited the poetry anthology Golden Treasury of the best Songs and Lyrical Poems in the English Language (1861, 1897).

Palio, the.Entry Details: - the horseraces held in Siena twice a year: on the festivals of Our Lady's Visitation (July 2) and of her Assumption (August 15), the race course 1S three times around the Campo, and in the race there 1S one horse representing each contrade, rival social groups which come from different districts of Siena.

Palla, Lunarda da.Entry Details: fl. 1454, prob. tutor and secretary of Sallustio MALATESTA, Sigismondo's son.

Palladio.Entry Details: - Andrea, 1518-80, Italian architect who adopted the principles of Roman architecture to the requirements of the Renaissance; his works include the SAN GIORGIO MAGGIORE and the Capuchin churches in Venice. English architects of the Georgian period developed the designs called "Palladian."

Palmer.Entry Details: Joseph, 1718-88, American soldier; as a colonel of the Colonal militia he participated in the defense of the coast near Boston, in 1777 appointed brigadier-general and given command of the Massachusetts militia defending Rhode Island.

Palmerston, Lord.Entry Details: Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston, 1784-1865, the English statesman; prime minister (1855-58; 1859-65).

Palux Laerna.Entry Details: Palus Lernae, the swamp of Lerna where Hercules killed the Hydra, the poisonous snake. (See: Propertius, II, XXVI, 48).

Pandone, Parcelio.Entry Details: 1405-85, Italian poet of the court of Naples; served Sigismondo MALATESTA at Rimini (1456) and wrote De amore Iovis in Isottam. (See: Basinio da PARMA).

Panisks.Entry Details: minor gods of the forest, half-man, half-goat, from (Gr) Paniskos, dim. of PAN.

Pao Sse.Entry Details: (Pao Ssu) C. 8th century BC, concubine of Emperor YEOU OUANG, earthquakes preceded her coming to the throne, and the great eclipse of the sun on 29 August 775 followed it. She enslaved the emperor and incited him to the wildest acts of folly.

Paphos.Entry Details: town on the SW coast of Cyprus; famous as a place of the worship of APHRODITE.

Paradiso.Entry Details: the third section of Dante's Divina Commedia.

Paris.Entry Details: the son of Priam, King of Troy; stole HELEN of Troy from her husband, Menelaus.

Parliament.Entry Details: the legislative body of Great Britain.

[Parma, Basinio da].Entry Details: Basinio de Basinii, ?1425-57, poet and humanist of Rimini; born in Parma, he was a noted student of Greek; engaged in a famous literary debate with Parcelio PANDONE on the values of Greek studies.

Paschi di detta Città.Entry Details: (It) Bank of ever mentioned city. (See: MONTE DEI PASCHI).

Pasepa.Entry Details: fl. AD 1269, a Lama who provided the Mongols with an alphabet; in gratitude, KUBLAI KHAN raised him to the rank of head Lama.

Pasiphae.Entry Details: wife of Minos, King of Crete; sister of CIRCE and mother of the Minotaur.

Passy.Entry Details: in the 18th century a village to the NW of Paris, in which the American delegation (FRANKLIN, DEANE, and Arthur LEE) stayed; now a fashionable section of Paris.

Pasti.Entry Details: Matteo de', d. 1468, Veronese sculptor and medalist; sent by Sigismondo MALATESTA to Candia to make a portrait of the Turkish emperor, MOHAMMED II, he was arrested by the Venetians, who suspected him of being in league with the Turks against them. He was released, however, and returned to Rimini.

\"Past runn'd Latium '\".Entry Details: variation of W. S. Landor, Pastruined Ilion Helen lives.

Patchin.Entry Details: Patchin Place, a court off Sixth Avenue, Greenwich Village, New York.

Paterson.Entry Details: William, 1658-1719, British financier, chief founder of the BANK OF ENGLAND (1694).

Paucity, Mt.Entry Details: a desolate range of mountains in Manchuria, called by the Chinese the "Mountains of Poverty. 11

Paul, St..Entry Details: d.c 67, the Christian apostle, missionary and martyr.

Pavia.Entry Details: capital of Pavia province of Lombardy, N Italy, the Church of San Michele in Pavia 1S an excellent example of 12th century Lombard Romanesque architecture.

Paxton.Entry Details: Charles, 1704-1788, British commissioner of customs at Boston and head of the Board of Commissioners; left America in 1776.

Pa Yang.Entry Details: Pan-yang, poss. the city of P'ing-yang in Shansi province. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IX, 485).

Pe.Entry Details: Pé-koan, (P'e-k'ou) the North Pass which lies to the north of NAN-KOAN; also the tribe of NUTCHÉ Tartars which takes its name from the region of the pass.

Peabody.Entry Details: George, 1795-1869, American financier and philanthropist; in 1835 he negotiated a loan from the British to save the finances of Maryland; became a London broker in 1837 and did much to promote Anglo-American relations.

[Pearse, Patrick Henry].Entry Details: 1879-1916, Irish author and Sinn Fein leader, commander in chief of the Irish forces in the Easter Rebellion (1916), executed after surrendering his troops.

[Pedro I].Entry Details: 1320-1367, King of Portugal (1357-67); son of Alfonso IV and "husband" of Ignez da CASTRO.

Pe1-kiu.Entry Details: (Pe1 Chü) fl. AD 607, he was sent by Emperor YANG-TI to be governor in SI-YU and turned his journey to good account by mapping the country.

[Peiping].Entry Details: (formerly Peking), the city in Hopeh province, NE China; capital of China during the YUAN and subsequent dynasties.

Pé-kin.Entry Details: (Pe Chin) d. BC 1063, ruler of the principality of LOU.

Pellegrini..Entry Details: Giampietro Domenico, under-secretary in the Italian Ministry of Finance (1943); appointed Minister of Finance (20 September 1943) in the government of the SALÖ Republic, official in the Consigliere Nazionale and the Corporazione della Previdenza e del Credito.

Peloponnesus.Entry Details: the south part of the mainland of Greece; also called MOREA.

pence of Peter.Entry Details: Peter's Pence, a hearth tax of one penny to support the Papacy.

Penn, John.Entry Details: ?1741-88, American Revolutionary leader; member of the CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1775-80) and a signer of the DECLARATION of Independence.

[Pennabill]].Entry Details: a town in the Apennines, SW of Rimini, between Mt. CARPEGNA and the Marecchia river; home of Giovanni MALATESTA.

Penthesilea.Entry Details: queen of the Amazons, she and her followers came to the and of Troy after the death of Hector.

Pentheus.Entry Details: grandson of CADMUS and King of Thebes; when DIONYSUS returned to Thebes, Pentheus denied his divinity and refused to worship him; advised by a stranger (the god in disguise) to spy on the woman worshippers, he was torn to pieces by them when discovered. (See Ovid, Metamorphoses, III, 511-733).

Perdicaris.Entry Details: Ion, an American who was kidnapped (1904) by the Moroccan brigand RAIS ULI, the affair gave rise to the slogan in America: "Perdicaris alive or Raisuli dead."

Péreira.Entry Details: Antoine Péreyra, fl. 1689, a Jesuit missionary in China, he served with GERBILLON on the commission to negotiate a treaty between China and Russia (1689).

Pergusa.Entry Details: Pergus, a lake in Sicily near the city of Enna, near the lake PERSEPHONE was seized by Pluto and carried off. (See: Ovid, Metamorphoses, V, 386).

Périgueux.Entry Details: capital of Dordogne department, SW France; the historical capital of Périgord.

Perimedes.Entry Details: member of the crew of ODYSSEUS. (See: Odyssey, XI, 23).

Perkeo.Entry Details: fl. 1720, fool in the court of Karl Philip, Perkeo's tub 1S the Great Vat of Heidelberg, which according to Scheffel's song was emptied by Perkeo alone, a wooden figure of Perkeo stands on the wall of the vat room.

per l'argine sinistra dienno volta.Entry Details: (It) would turn to the left side. (See: Inferno, 21, 136).

per legem terrae.Entry Details: (L) by the law of the land.

per pares et legem terrae.Entry Details: (L) by peers and the law of the land. (See: John Adams, Works, III, 471-72).

Perpetua.Entry Details: St. Perpetua, d. 203, a Carthaginian martyr.

Perseis.Entry Details: or Perse, mother of CIRCE and PASIPHAE.

Persephone.Entry Details: the daughter of ZEUS and DEMETER, she was carried off to the lower world by Hades, but was allowed to return to the world in the spring and summer.

Perugia.Entry Details: city in central Italy, capital of Umbria; site of an excellent 14th century cathedral and a fountain with sculptures by Nicolò and Giovanni Pisano.

Pèsaro.Entry Details: port city and capital of Pesaro e Urbino province in central Italy; it was held by the Malatesta's in the 13th century, then by the Sforza, and then by the dukes of Urbino until 1631, when it passed to the Holy See.

Pétain.Entry Details: Henri Philippe, 1856-1951, marshal of France; convicted of "intelligence with the enemy" (1945) and sentenced to life imprisonment; during the First World War he saved France by halting the Germans at Verdun (1916).

Petano.Entry Details: poss. Coltano, near Pisa, location of the DTC, 1945.

Peter I.Entry Details: Peter the Great, 1672-1725; emperor (1721-25) and tsar (1682-1725) of Russia; founder of the modern Russian state.

Petty, Sir William.Entry Details: 2nd Earl of Shelbourne, 1st Marquis of Lansdowne, 1737-1805, English statesman; secretary of state under Pitt (1766-68), attempted conciliation toward the American colonies; first lord of the treasury and prime minister (1782-83); conceded American independence.

Pe-y.Entry Details: (Pe I), the ancestral house of FEI-TSEI, who became Prince of TSIN and founder of the house which was to become the TSIN dynasty.

Peyan.Entry Details: Poyang Hu, a lake in N Kiangsi province, SE China; China's second largest lake, into which flows the HAN river.

Peyen.Entry Details: Péyen-témour (P'eyen Temur) d. AD 1362, King of the Koreans.

Péyen.Entry Details: Péyen-tiémour (P'eyen T'iehmur) fl. AD 1450, a Mongol general who took charge of the captured Emperor YNG-TSONG; he also participated in the Mongol attack on Peiping (1450).

Phaebidas.Entry Details: Phoebidas, a Spartan commander, who seized the stronghold of Thebes in Boeotia (382 BC). (See: John Adams, Works, IV, 286).

Phaethusa.Entry Details: a daughter of HELIOS. (See: Odyssey, XII, 132).

Pharamond.Entry Details: C. 5th century BC, legendary king of the Saline Franks; supposedly he published the code of the Salic laws, which included penal and civil laws.

Pharisees.Entry Details: one of the two great Jewish religious parties that arose in the synagogue; they insisted on strict adherence to the laws of the Jewish religion, both the Written and the Oral Law. The other party, the Sadducees, accepted only the teaching of the Torah.

Philadelphia.Entry Details: the city of Pennsylvania; meeting place of the First CONTINENTAL CONGRESS (1774), Second Continental Congress (1775-76; 1777; 1778-89), Constitutional Convention (1787); served as capital of the US (1790-1800).

Philiasia.Entry Details: Phliasia, the territory of Phlius, a town in the north-east of the Peloponnesus.

Philip.Entry Details: Philip IV, 1605-65, King of Spain (1621-65), his portrait by VELÁSQUEZ hangs in the PRADO.

Phlegethon.Entry Details: the river of fire in Hades.

Phoenician cities.Entry Details: the cities on the Atlantic coast of Africa which were founded by HANNO: KARIKON, GUTTA, AKRA, MELI, ARAMBO.

Phrygia.Entry Details: ancient country in W central Asia Minor.

phtheggometha/thasson.Entry Details: (Gr) let us raise our voices without delay. (See: Appendix A).

Piacenza.Entry Details: town in the region of Veneto, N Italy.

Piazza.Entry Details: prob. the Piazza di San Marco, Venice.

Piazza Chapel.Entry Details: (It) Chapel Square. (The Piazza del Duomo, Siena).

Piccinino, Giacomo.Entry Details: d. 1465, son of Niccolò PICCINI- NO; an Italian condottiere, connected by marriage with Francesco SFORZA; murdered at Naples.

Piccinino.Entry Details: Niccolò, 1375-1444, Italian condottiere serving Fillippo Maria VISCONTI, Duke of Milan; captured Bologna (1438) and ruled it until 1443.

Piccolomini, Aeneas Silvius..Entry Details: Enea Silvio de, 1405-64, Pope Pius II (1458-64); an author, humanist, and patron of writers; in literature he is known as Aeneas Silvius.

Piccolomin, Nicolò.Entry Details: poss. Francesco di Niccolò Piccolomini, 1520-1604, professor of philosophy at the University of Siena.

Pickering, Tim.Entry Details: Timothy, 1745-1829, American general and statesman; during the Revolution he was a member of the Board of War (1777) and quartermaster general (1780-85); Postmaster General of the US (1791-95); Secretary of War (1795) and then Secretary of State (1795-1800). John ADAMS dismissed him from his last office because Pickering's anti-French attitude was not in line with Adams' foreign policy and because of Pickering's political manipulations.

Pickthall, Marmaduke William.Entry Details: 1875-1936, English novelist living in the Near East; he was converted to Mohammedism.

Pien.Entry Details: Pien-kuan-chi (Pien Chuan-shih), a woman of the principality of SONG; CONFUCIUS married her in BC 532, but divorced her later. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, II, 190).

Pig and Piffle.Entry Details: prob. the English magazine Sport and Country.

P1-kan.Entry Details: (P1 Kan) 12th century BC, uncle of CHEOU-SIN, last emperor of the YIN dynasty, when P1-kan objected to the excesses of Cheou-sin, the emperor had him disembowelled on the spot. (See: Analects, XVIII, 1).

Pilate, Pontius.Entry Details: fl. AD 33, procurator of Judea under Emperor Tiberius, tried and condemned Christ.

[Pili, Ugolini dei].Entry Details: fl. 1420, Italian soldier serving as captain under Pandolfo MALATESTA.

Pilkington, Sir J..Entry Details: Sir John, fl. 1454, the case of Sir John Pilkington (32 H. VI. 25) was one which substantiated the fact that Ireland is a dominion separate and divided from England. (See: Coke, Reports, 7, 22b).

Pillars, the..Entry Details: the Pillars of Heracles. (See: STRAIT OF GIBRALTAR).

Pinckney.Entry Details: Charles Cotesworth, 1746-1825, American statesman; sent to France on a special mission (1796-97) but because the French refused to recognize his status he was forced to leave France for Amsterdam, there he was approached by members of the French government who offered terms under which negotiations might start (the main point was the Jay Treaty), this incident became the famous XYZ Affair.

Ping Tching.Entry Details: (P'ing-ch'êng), capital of the kingdom of OUEI (376-494).

Pinyang.Entry Details: Ping-ngan (Ping-an), the modern city of Keijo (or Seoul) in Korea; served as capital of the Korean dynasty (1392-1910).

Piombino.Entry Details: town in Tuscany; ruled by the VISCONTI family.

piquée de ce badinage.Entry Details: (Fr) stung by this banter. (See: Mailla, Histoire Générale, IV, 500).

[Pisano, Antonio]..Entry Details: ?1397-1455, Veronese painter and medalist, employed by Sigismondo MALATESTA in the building of the Tempio, patronized by Lionello d'ESTE; also known as Vittore Pisano.

Pistoja.Entry Details: Pistoia, town in N Tuscany, near Florence.

Pitro, Mr..Entry Details: a blacksmith in the service of Francesco SFORZA.

Pitt.Entry Details: William, "the Elder Pitt, 11 1708-1778, the English statesman, was opposed to the STAMP ACT and British taxation of the American Colonies.

Pitt..Entry Details: William, "the Younger Pitt, 11 1759-1806, the English statesman, prime minister (1783-1801; 1804-06).

[Pius XI].Entry Details: Achille Ambrogio Damiano Ratti, 1857-1939, Pope (1922-39), subprefect of the Vatican Library (1911-18), nuncio (1919-20), cardinal and archbishop of Milan (1921).

placet sic.Entry Details: (L) it pleases thus. (placet: an affirmative vote, yea).

Placuit oculis.Entry Details: (L) she pleased the eyes. (See: "ET AMAVA PERDUTAMENTE...").

Plan of Government.Entry Details: The Plan, the first of three sections into which Charles Francis Adams has divided John Adams' major works relating to the form of American government; the other sections are titled: The Model, The Defence. (See: John Adams, Works, IV, 185-VI, 217).

Plarr.Entry Details: Victor Gustave, 1863-1929, librarian of the Royal College of Surgeons of England; author of In The Dorian Mood (1896) and other works.

Pleiades.Entry Details: the cluster of stars in the constellation of Taurus; the seven daughters of Atlas.

Plotinus.Entry Details: ? 205-270, the Roman philosopher, a leader of the Neoplatonic school.

Plura diafana.Entry Details: (L) more things diaphanous. (See: Grosseteste, De iride seu de iride et speculo, ed. Baur, 73).

Pluto.Entry Details: a name of Hades; god of the nether world. (See: PERSEPHONE).

Poggio.Entry Details: Gian Francesco Poggio Bracciolini, 1380-1459, Italian humanist; known for his discoveries of lost Latin classics in various monasteries.

Poicebot.Entry Details: Gaubertz, a monk of Provence who became a troubadour. (See. Make It New, 25).

Potters.Entry Details: formerly spelled Poictiers; city of Vienne department W central France, site of a 12th century Romanesque Gothic cathedral and the remains of the palace of the former counts of Poitou.

[Poitiers, Guillaume].Entry Details: 1071-1127, ninth Duke of Aquitaine and seventh Count of Potters; the earliest troubadour whose songs are extant; the grandfather of ELEANOR of Aquitaine.

Pola.Entry Details: or Pulj, a fortified seaport at the S tip of the Istrian Peninsula, NW Yugoslavia; S of Trieste.

Pole, Cardinal.Entry Details: Reginald Pole, 1500-58; created cardinal by Pope Paul III (1536); opposed to the divorce and religious reforms of HENRY VIII.

Polenta..Entry Details: Ostasio da Polenta; an ally of the Venetians in 1441, he was yet deprived by them of Ravenna and exiled to Candia with his family.

Polhonac.Entry Details: Héracle III, Viscount of Polignac. His wife, Adelande de Claustra, was admired by Guillaume de Saint-Didier, who addressed love-songs to her, she agreed to accept him if so urged by her husband, whereupon Guillaume wrote the song (Dona, 1eu vos soy messatgiers) in which a husband intercedes with his wife in the interest of a rejected lover. The Viscount received the song, admired it, sang it to his wife, and thus "set the feast" for Guillaume.

Poliorcetes.Entry Details: (Gr) taker of cities; the epithet was applied to Sigismondo MALATESTA by PISANELLO.

Pollon d'anthropon iden.Entry Details: (Gr) And of many men he saw (the cities, and knew their mind). (See: Appendix A).

Polo.Entry Details: Marco, ?1254-1324?, Venetian traveler; visited KUBLAI KHAN in 1275 and returned to Venice in 1295. In 1296 he was taken prisoner by the Genoese against whom Polo, with the Venetians, was fighting; he dictated his memoirs while in prison in Genoa.

Pomona.Entry Details: the old Italian goddess of fruit trees.

Ponce.Entry Details: Juan Ponce de León, ?1460-1521, Spanish governor of Puerto Rico and discoverer of Florida, which he found while looking for the Fountain of Youth (Easter Sunday 1513).

Pondo.Entry Details: locality in central Italy; taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

Pone metum, / Metum, nec deus laedit.Entry Details: (L) Lay aside fear, / fear, nor does God harm. (See: Tibullus, III, X, 15).

Pong.Entry Details: Pong-choul-hien (Pêng-shui-hsien), a town in Szechwan province.

Pongchan.Entry Details: (Peng-shan), a district city in the province of Szechwan.

[Por, Odon].Entry Details: 1883- , Italian writer on social and economic problems and on Italian Fascism.

Portoferraio.Entry Details: seaport of Elba Island; where Napoleon lived during his exile (1814-15).

Possum ego naturae / non meminisse tuae!.Entry Details: (L) Can I forget thy nature! (See: Propertius, II, xx, 28).

Potemkin.Entry Details: Grigori Aleksandrovich, 1739-91, Russian statesman; the chief favorite of Catherine II, he was created field marshal in 1784; constructed a fleet in the Black Sea, created prince of Tauris (1787).

pouvrette et ancienne oncques lettre ne.Entry Details: (Fr) povrette et ancienne oncques lettre ne leuz. poor and old never did I read a letter. (See: Villon, Testament, "Ballade Pour Prier Nostre Dame").

[Poynings, Sir Edward].Entry Details: 1459-1521, English soldier and diplomat, as governor of Ireland, he summoned the Drogheda Parliament (1494) that enacted Poynings's law providing that every act of that parliament must be approved by the English privy council to become valid.

praemunires.Entry Details: (Law) offenses made punishable by forfeiture of property and imprisonment; also the form of writ for prosecuting such offenses.

Prataline.Entry Details: locality in central Italy, taken from Sigismondo MALATESTA by the peace terms imposed by PIUS II (c. 1460).

Prayer: hands uplifted and pities those.Entry Details: from The Fourth Satire of Dr. John Donne, versifyed by Alexander Pope; variation of Henry IV, part 2, III, i, 31.

Pré Catalan.Entry Details: a restaurant in the Bois de Boulogne, Paris.

Predappio.Entry Details: town in NE Italy, where MUSSOLINI was born.

preraphaelite.Entry Details: a society of artists formed in England in 1848 and known as the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood; the original members were Holman Hunt, John E. Millais, D. G. Rossetti, James Collinson, Thomas Woolner, Frederick George Stephens, and W. M. Rossetti.

President of Magdalen.Entry Details: prob. Sir Herbert Warren, 1853-1930, president of Magdalen College, Oxford (1885-1928).

Presqu'isle.Entry Details: Presque Isle, once a military fort in N Maine, first controlled by the British in Canada and then relinquished to the Americans; now a village.

Preston.Entry Details: Thomas, captain of the British troops involved in the Boston Massacre (1770); he was defended by John ADAMS, who obtained an acquittal.

Priapus.Entry Details: god of fertility; son of DIONYSUS and APHRODITE.

Price.Entry Details: Richard, 1723-91, Welsh moral and political philosopher; attacked the British policy toward the American Revolution in his Observations on Civil Liberty and War with America (1776); was a friend of Benjamin FRANKLIN and John ADAMS.

Primavera.Entry Details: a reference to Giovanna, the lady of Guido CAVALCANTI, to whom he addressed some of his ballate. (See: La Vita Nuova, XXIV, 20-23).

Primrose.Entry Details: one of the three principal characters in Rene CREVEL's Les Pieds dans le plat (1933), where she is Lady Primerose, marquise of Sussex.

Princes Mogul.Entry Details: the princes of the Mongolian tribes which, in AD 1635, formed a confederation under the hegemony of TAI-TSONG, the Manchu leader.

Prishnip.Entry Details: prob. Gavrilo Princip, who assassinated Francis Ferdinand at Sarajevo (28 June 1914).

Procuratio nomine patris.Entry Details: (L) procuration in the name of the father.

Programma di Verona, 11.Entry Details: the Program of Verona, the manifesto detailing the principles of action of the Fascist Republican Party, SALÖ Republic, October 1943.

Proteus.Entry Details: a sea-deity, the guardian of the herds of POSEIDON; he had knowledge of future events and would disclose this knowledge if one could catch and hold him while he changed shape.

Protot, Robert.Entry Details: prob. Robert Pinot, Secrétaire Général du COMITÉ DES FORGES in the first World War, serving under the presidency of François de WENDEL; author of Le Comité des Forges de France au service de la nation (Août 1914-Novembre 1918) published in 1919.

Province, the.Entry Details: the royal province of New York, established 1685-1776, the area of the present state of New York.

Province House.Entry Details: the official building of the Province of Friesland, the Netherlands.

Psellos.Entry Details: Michael Constantine Psellus, 1018-1105?, Byzantine philosopher, politician, writer, and early Neoplatonist.

Pujo.Entry Details: Arsène Paulin, 1861-1939, American lawyer and legislator; member of the House of Representatives (1903-13), chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency (1911-13) and head of the so-called "money trust" investigation.

Purtheo, Aloysius.Entry Details: fl. 1450, prob. Benedictine abbot of the basilica SANT APOLLINAIRE, Ravenna; he agreed, for 200 gold florins, to allow Sigismondo MALATESTA to take marble from the church and use it in the TEMPIO.

Puvis.Entry Details: Pierre Puvis de Chavannes, 1824-98, French mural-1st; some of his best work 1S in the Sorbonne and the Panthéon.

Pym, Bill.Entry Details: William, a pseudonym used by a writer on the side of the English in the London Evening Post (1765); John ADAMS answered Pym under the pseudonym of Earl CLARENDON.

Pyrenees.Entry Details: the mountain range on the French-Spanish border.
